name: Martin SCHULZ
text: I declare the session suspended on Thursday, 15 September 2016, to be resumed.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which is Last Friday, the world bid farewell to Shimon Peres, this extraordinary statesman and tireless defender of peace. President Peres had a vision of a pacified Middle East in which Israel would live non-violently with its Palestinian neighbors and Arab states. Shimon Peres pursued this vision, and he implemented it with his participation in the Oslo Peace Agreement in September 1993. He was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1994 alongside Yitzhak Rabin and Yasser Arafat for this milestone in the Middle East peace process. Shimon Peres was a friend of Europe. He has honoured us several times here in the European Parliament with his presence and spoken to us. I think you will agree with me when I say that his personality, charisma and ideas have inspired us every time he has been with us. His message was simple and clear: never give up fighting for peace! The legacy of Shimon Peres is enormous, and it is now the responsibility of the next generation of politicians in Israel to continue on its path of diplomacy, dialogue and reconciliation. On behalf of the European Parliament, I would like to express our deepest sympathy to his family, to his friends, to the people close to him and to the Israeli people. I would ask you to rise from your seats in honour of Shimon Peres. (The House rose and observed a minute's silence)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Colleagues! Tomorrow, Tuesday, we will be able to welcome the Secretary-General of the United Nations, Mr Ban Ki-moon, and the Minister for the Environment of the French Republic, Mrs Ségoléne Royal, in her capacity as President-in-Office of the COP-21 Climate Conference. I will propose to you later an amendment to tomorrow's agenda to hold a brief formal sitting on the possible ratification of the Paris agreement tomorrow in this House, at which the Secretary-General of the United Nations would like to address us here in plenary. After the formal sitting, the vote here in plenary on the approval of this agreement by this House will take place. This vote will, of course, depend on whether the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and The European Health and Social Affairs makes a positive recommendation for tomorrow's decision in plenary. Tomorrow, it will be up to us to take the final political step towards the formal ratification of this agreement by the EU and its Member States. If ratification is ratified here in this House tomorrow, the Paris Agreement could enter into force less than a year after its adoption – just in time for the COP-22 climate conference in Marakkesch. Tomorrow's vote here and the binding nature of the Member States of the European Union would also achieve the minimum quorum that the United Nations needs to implement the climate agreement worldwide. That is why tomorrow's vote will certainly be extremely important.

name: Ryszard Antoni LEGUTKO
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – I request the removal of the point on so-called women's rights in Poland. First, the interference of the Union institutions in this matter is inadmissible under Article 5(1) and (2) of the Treaty on European Union, where it reads: 'all competences not admitted to the Union in the Treaties belong to the Member States'. There is nothing in the Provisions of the Treaties which confers on the Union competence in matters of abortion. Secondly, that interpretation was confirmed by the Court of Justice of the European Union in Case 150/90 Society for the Protection of the Unborn Children v. Grogan and that ruling are still in force. Thirdly, the interference of the Union institutions with regard to abortion is also not justified by the Charter of Fundamental Rights, where Article 51(2) reads: 'This Charter does not establish new competences or tasks for the Union, nor does it alter the competences and tasks set out in the Treaties'. In conclusion, any interference by the European Parliament in that matter is manifestly extra-legal.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA

name: Marek JUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I wanted to ask why you did not give me the floor because I wanted to know what the real meaning of this vote, which we have just held, is. name: Martin SCHULZ

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Mr President, I would like to enquire about the equal treatment of Member States within the EU, because in virtually every EU Member State there is a popular movement requesting consideration of certain legislative measures. For example, in Finland, one such request with 60 000 signatures, on issues relating to the right to abortion, was also deliberated upon in the parliament, yet we did not discuss that issue. Why is this one so? The current legislative measures are popular, societal initiatives, not governmental ones. Why are we considering it during this session?

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mrs Fotyga, I will read the text in the Minutes again and look into where you referred to the Rules of Procedure. Wednesday: The GUE Group requests that a Statement by the Commission on the situation in Hungary, on the referendum campaign and aspects of European international asylum law, be put on the agenda as the fifth item in the afternoon following the debate on women's rights in Poland.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, yesterday a referendum was held in Hungary to ask hungarians if they wanted the European Union to make it compulsory to set up refugee quotas in the country. Hungarians voted, including, but not in sufficient numbers for the result of this referendum to be validated. This is a victory for those who have called for a boycott. What worries us and what we want to debate are the conditions of this campaign, in terms of European and international human rights rules and, in particular, the Geneva Convention.  I have in my hands the posters of the official campaign entitled "Tudta?" ("Did you know?"). The statements proposed are appalling in that they manipulate amalgamations, particularly between terrorism and immigration. I will take an example: 'Brussels wants to set up the equivalent of a city of illegal immigrants in Hungary'. The quota in Hungary, if it had been accepted, is 1,294 people. Really a very small town, not to say a village. That is 0.01% of the Hungarian population, not enough to upset the values of Hungary, it seems to me.  Are such lies worthy of the values of the European Union? It seems to me that the European Parliament should at least debate it and have the opinion of the Commission, as well as on the evolution of immigration and asylum legislation.  That is why we want a debate on this subject, Mr President, and we call for the European Parliament to vote by public vote.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: Mr President, I believe that the issue that was raised in the Hungarian referendum is a question of European significance.  The reactions observed within the Hungarian citizen body are reactions that are observed elsewhere in Europe. So I think it is quite appropriate that we should take a moment to reflect on what happened in Hungary, but from a truly European perspective. This should not be a festival of finger pointing , I do not find the right expression for it in French , but an exercise in collective reflection on how we deal with the challenge of migration and refugees. In my view, it will come out of the debate quite clearly that there is only one together that we can remedy or, I would say, deal with it.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: – Mr President, my group does not want it to be discussed in this House, but it wants it discussed in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and discussed in plenary at a later date. For what reason? We are concerned about the situation in Hungary - this Parliament has debated this several times, because the policies of the Hungarian Government, the Government of Orban, are continually on the sidelines, if not outside the fundamental values of the Union. And so we've had that debate. But this debate has always been used by Mr Orban to raise a non-existent conflict between the European Parliament and Hungary.  Yesterday it was shown that the conflict exists between the Government of Orban and its citizens. And their citizens left the Orban government in a clear way. They rejected their populist temptation. Let us not darken his defeat. Let's focus on his defeat. Let us take the matter to the LIBE Commission. Let us prepare the debate and bring it back to the house.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on Norbert Neuser's report on behalf of the Committee on Development on the future of relations between the ACP countries and the EU after 2020 (2016/2053(INI)) (A8-0263/2016).

name: Norbert NEUSER
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Since 2000, the Cotonou Agreement has been in force between the 28 EU Member States and the African, Caribbean and Pacific countries. This agreement is unique in the world. It is the result of close cooperation between our countries in Europe and 78 countries, mainly developing countries, referring to the HYPERLINK 'http://www.bpb.de/nachschlagen/lexika/lexikon-der-wirtschaft/20027/lome-abkommen' Lomé Agreements I and II from the 1970s. The Cotonou Agreement expires in a few years. It is therefore good to set the course early enough now as to what will happen beyond 2020.  The European Parliament is well placed. We are presenting this report today, and therefore our position on ACP relations. The Commission will follow suit in a few weeks or months; then the Council is called upon. The negotiations in which the Commission was represented have shown that we, as parliamentarians, are roughly in line with the Commission. That is why it would be good if we could achieve a broad majority in Parliament, because there is opposition in the Member States, in the European Council, also in some countries, against the continuation of this agreement.  Why do I believe that this agreement should be continued? There is a legal framework that we would not have would have without this agreement after 2020.  We must also see that, as Europeans and also as parliamentarians, we are better off overall. Acceptance among parliamentarians could be better, as could the commitment of the Member States. I would point out that, since 2013, the Member States that each held the Presidency of the Council have refused to host the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly. These were Ireland, Greece and the Netherlands, and I hope that perhaps next year Malta, when it has the Presidency of the Council, will behave differently.  The importance of the ACP Agreement, in three pillars, is, firstly, development cooperation, the political dimension and economic and trade cooperation. During the debate on the continuation, it has often been said that we are not discussing enough human rights violations on the European side with our African, Caribbean and Pacific partners. However, this is also up to us, because the Cotonou Agreement does indeed see this possibility in Articles 8 and 96, and we should continue to take this into account in the future, when the agreement is extended. We have to address new challenges in an agreement after 2020. I mention climate change, migration, the new SDGs and the fight against terrorism – global issues that we can solve well within the framework of the EU-ACP and where we work with our partners on solutions.  What do we need in the future? We need better regional orientation, because not all the issues that the small island states or the large countries such as Nigeria and South Africa have touch, and that is why I think we need new regional structures under a common roof, and cushioned by the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly in parliament.

name: Norbert NEUSER
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Committee on Development and the rapporteur, Mr Neuser, for the report on the future of ACP—EU relations beyond 2020. I also thank the Committee on Foreign Affairs, the Committee on International Trade and the Committee on Budgets for their opinions. This report is an important milestone. The Cotonou Agreement binds us with almost 80 countries in the world. We have a unique opportunity ahead of us. Let us put the EU global strategy into practice and let us use a future partnership as a vehicle for implementing the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development jointly. I am pleased to express support for this report. Let me point out some of the features I find most important. We are aiming for a partnership that is flexible enough to cope with a radically, and rapidly, changing international environment. We should aim to address effectively common challenges and take advantage of economic opportunities to deliver peace and prosperity for our people, both in the European Union and in the ACP countries. We need a partnership that reflects and reinforces EU interests, objectives and means, as well as those of our ACP partners. This new partnership should keep what has worked, but we should also use the opportunity to improve, or create new ways of working, where weaknesses have been shown. Our main concern should be to keep the essential elements as global safeguards, such as respect for human rights, democracy and the rule of law, as well as good governance. This is clearly fundamental. We should also maintain and reinforce our regular political dialogue with our partner countries. International commitments, such as the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development or the Paris climate agreement, should be central references in a future partnership. Enhancing dialogue with ACP countries in order to forge global alliances in multilateral settings offers a new perspective for a future partnership. An excellent case in point was the final round of negotiations during COP 21 in Paris. The fight to eradicate poverty and combat inequalities is at the heart of our policies and we know that efforts should be maintained. We also expect strong commitment on the part of the ACP countries. Any future framework that links the ACP to the EU should learn from the positive aspects of Cotonou, including its legally binding nature. The world around us is evolving and so are the roles of organisations and institutions. The partnership should recognise this and give due consideration to all levels, both continental and regional. It should equally reflect on how to involve national parliaments and other actors at local level, as well as non-state actors, in our project. The impact of the private sector should also be fostered since it has proven to be an essential motor for development. The report encourages engagement with additional countries as well as our current ACP partners. For the sake of geographical and political coherence, this certainly merits consideration. While I trust that many honourable Members share most of these opinions, I look forward now to hearing your comments.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: drafts member of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. – Madam President, as we know, the Association Agreements have had numerous negative impacts on the economies of the ACP countries, so a new partnership, fair, peer-to-peer, is needed to respect the sovereignty of countries, seeking to meet basic needs and respect for human rights. The new partnership should promote the development of countries' productive capacities, protect traditional agriculture and combat land grabbing. We support the United Nations decision to create a legal instrument for businesses to respect human rights, to end labour exploitation, modern slavery, illicit capital flow and the financing of terrorism or conflict. It is important to underline the universality of human rights enshrined in international law, including international law for migrants and refugees, which must be respected, as well as the Geneva Convention. Finally, I would like to point out the importance of ending foreign interference in domestic affairs, as well as the end of neocolonial policies and the dismantling of all foreign military bases.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. – Madam President, our economic and political relations with the African, Caribbean and Pacific countries have never been more important, and this report sets out three key principles for our future relations with those countries beyond 2020 and the current Cotonou Agreement. Firstly, the sustainable development goals must be at the heart of our future partnership. Secondly, any post-Cotonou agreement must remain legally binding and enforceable. And thirdly, we must strengthen the involvement of civil society and improve monitoring structures. Our trade policy and economic partnership agreements (EPAs) are central to this strategy. These regional instruments should support the overall framework agreement. However, there is a real danger here. A new framework agreement will only come once Cotonou expires after 2020, and yet we are already voting on the content of those EPAs, now and in the coming months, and the agreements so far put before this House have been a long way away from the principles contained in this report. I therefore urge colleagues not only to support Norbert Neuser’s excellent report but also to follow through when considering the ratification of future EPAs.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: rapporteur of the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. – Madam President, Commissioner, from the Committee on Budgets we consider that the coincidence at the time of the completion of the current financial framework (2014-2020) and the Cotonou Agreement gives us a perfect opportunity for the European Development Fund to be included in European budgets at last.  To this end, we consider it essential that the Commission should start working on a roadmap from now on and present it before the next financial framework. We believe that it would give greater legitimacy and effectiveness to the Fund and, above all, allow us to coordinate and improve the coherence of Union policies and existing instruments.  I would like to remind you that the fight against poverty is essential to address the causes of migration and forced displacement and that this must therefore remain one of the Union's overall objectives. By this I would like to say that the new instruments put forward by the Commission, such as the investment plan for Africa or the trust fund, cannot in any way compromise the policy of development cooperation, nor can they use funds for purposes other than those we have already discussed.

name: Maurice PONGA
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank our colleague, Norbert Neuser, for the work that has been done and for the excellent cooperation on this issue. This report is important because it sets out our priorities for the future of our relations with the ACP countries and will, I hope, guide the European Commission in its proposals.  I am convinced that we must use Cotonou's achievements and improve it in order to respond to new global challenges such as migration or climate change. We can't start from scratch. We need to move forward and advance what already exists.  Thus, a legally binding text must be kept aimed at the entire ACP group, even if the regional dimension needs to be better taken into account. I think it is important to include our partnership after 2020 as part of the new Sustainable Development Goals and to insist that human rights and good governance are the cornerstones of our partnership with the ACP countries.  If we call for a budgetisation of the European Development Fund in our report, it must be subject to two preconditions. First, the maintenance of existing envelopes and, secondly, the creation of an instrument to finance security development-related expenditures. Indeed, I share the idea that there can be no development without peace and that security is a prerequisite for development. We therefore need a tool to address these issues.  In this regard, I am pleased that the report supports the idea of taking overseas countries and territories out of the European Development Fund and proposes the creation of a financial instrument specific to them. This is a new step that must lead, from 2020, to better reaffirm the European membership of our overseas countries and territories and to promote their role as ambassadors of the European Union by defending our values in neighbouring developing countries.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, Commissioner, I would first like to thank Mr Neuser for the report he has prepared for us, which I think is a very comprehensive report which will allow a roadmap for Parliament to participate in the renewal of the Cotonou Agreement. This is an agreement that has allowed us to have a political dialogue with a good number of countries on different continents and which has strengthened the external action of the European Union. It is also an agreement that has allowed us to take part in conflict prevention and peace work once these conflicts have flowed. It has also allowed us to participate in the protection of human rights, to provide good governance, to advance democratic processes. I have to point out, however, that the results with regard to the Economic Partnership Agreements have been very debatable, which must certainly be reviewed. But times are changing and times have already changed, and the situation now of these countries and the European Union is not the same situation as when the Cotonou Agreement was first addressed. Now are times to work among peers; these are times of mutual respect; are times of rebalancing to balance our relationships; and are therefore times to open ourselves up to a new horizon for the next twenty years, through collaboration without one-way action.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: for the ECR Group. Madam President! There are some who believe that you can create growth by making income redistribution. I don't think that's what the past 50 years of world history have been able to do. What is driving growth and prosperity and, fortunately, political rights such as democracy and freedom, that is free trade. The fact that nations and actors can act freely and unhindered when they have to exchange goods and other good causes, it creates growth! And that is what we need in relation to the partner countries we are talking about today. A great deal has happened since the first agreements were concluded, but it is also time that we looked inwards in relation to many of the challenges of a more dogmatic nature that we in the European Union are presenting. I cannot help but think of the whole support that exists in the agricultural sector, which is extremely protectionist and prevents, for example, agriculture in many of the partner countries we are talking to from acting freely in relation to European producers.  We also need to better assess the programmes we put into the lake. When I was preparing for today, I looked back and examined when we actually last received special reports from the Court of Auditors, which reviews the aid programmes in which the ACP countries are part. And so we have to go back more than ten years to find a thorough account of all the support programmes that we have put into the sea. That's not good enough! Not at all when you look at the criticisms that were made at the time. There is therefore a great need for us to re-look at all the cases.  Overall, however, there are many good considerations from Mr Tsipras. Mr Neuser, and we can support the report, but we really need more work if this is to work.

name: Paavo VÄYRYNEN
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the ALDE Group welcomes the report by the Committee on Development on the future of relations between the countries of Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific and the European Union. As the Cotonou Agreement expires in 2020, we want to replace it with a new cooperation agreement focusing on the 2030 Agenda for all the countries of the world and the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals. The Cotonou Agreement has been aimed at reducing poverty in african, Caribbean and Pacific countries and supporting them in their integration into the world economy. Unfortunately, insufficient progress has been made towards achieving the above objectives. The next agreement must enable cooperation to be deepened and enhanced in accordance with the will of the Member States, so that we can contribute to positive developments not only in the economic field, but also in the areas of peace and security, human rights, the rule of law, migration, climate change and, more broadly, the protection of the environment.  Much has happened since 2000, when the Cotonou Agreement was signed. The structure of the partnership must be adapted to meet the new challenges and coordinated with regional agreements and organisations.  The potential of the partnership is considerable. Together, we will form an important bloc with a common institutional framework and a large budget, the European Development Fund.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, I deeply regret that this report is a missed opportunity to make a difference in the relationship between the European Union and the countries of sub-Saharan Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific, that is, the poorest countries in the world.  We should encourage a way out of the circle of poverty in which the European Union is often part of the problem, not the solution.  I find it unacceptable that this report does not put at the heart of debt settlement, which keeps so many States in a constant state of subordination to their creditors. Nor does it attempt to end illicit capital flows or tax evasion, which empty their economies from domestic resources. These countries are subject to constant exposure, as large amounts of capital generated in them return to Europe or tax havens, and that's called stealing.  All of this has only one name: financial neocolonialism. Basing development aid on asymmetric trade relations increases inequality and poverty, condemning these countries to a state of perpetual subjugation and dependence.  Sustainable development goals are supposed to be at the heart of the new agreement and yet are only an ornamental element. The fundamental pillars of ACP-EU relations should be the fight against poverty and inequality through endogenous development, respecting their own space for States to implement the policies that best suit their citizens, not European businesses.  We all have our contradictions, but there are some red lines and some indispensable principles, and that is why I will not support this report with my vote.

name: Maria HEUBUCH
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner, Norbert Neuser, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work Many thanks to you for your work, for a report that sets out in great detail how cooperation between the EU and ACP countries can be organised. However, I believe that the rapporteur and the Committee on Development are committing themselves too early to a particular position, and that is why we Greens voted against it. The work in the committee was almost finished before the results of the evaluation of the Cotonou Agreement became known. Nor was it waited until possible scenarios and forms of cooperation were also detailed. And without this important basis, we Greens do not want to commit ourselves rashly.  It is important to us to make evidence-based decisions for a truly viable future agreement. Yes, the European Union has a long tradition of cooperation with the ACP countries, and that has been a very important cooperation. After all, the debate now on the future of our relationship with the ACP is not taking place in a vacuum! We have before us the revision of the European Consensus. In June, the High Representative of the European Union presented the EU's global strategy. We have the SDGs. You yourself, Commissioner, spoke of the climate agreement.  In other words, a great deal of things are changing, and we should use this to approach all possibilities here, to deal with all possibilities, to look at what has not worked so well in cooperation. Finally, we also need to answer difficult questions: the questions about the financing, the legal obligation or the future structure of the partnership, including how we can develop regional cooperation in detail. Double structures must be dismantled. I am convinced that whatever we choose for the future, we do not have to start from scratch, because we can build on good cooperation and now have the opportunity to move something new forward here.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, First of all, I would like to congratulate Mr Neuser on the excellent work he has done in his report, a report on which we voted in favour in the Committee on Development and with which we share the concern to draw up and give the European Parliament a position on the future of the Cotonou Agreement after 2020.  We recognise that all too often the European Parliament has lagging behind in making its position known on issues and issues that bring together trade, human rights and development. For our part, too, there has been a desire to make the ACP-EU partnership effective and adapted to the current and future challenges that will be present. Although we are in favour of the approach advocated by Mr Neuser, we must always remember that, in the four years leading up to 2020, changing conditions could lead to the positions of the report being exceeded. Therefore, on the assumption that the current situation is that we have not been able to influence the very serious problems caused by the direct and indirect interests of the various European states and multinationals and not in the ACP countries, we need a solid legal framework with instruments capable of adequately addressing the very serious problems in the sectors for which the agreement with the ACP countries was designed to be a good solution.  We should be far-sighted enough to predict and think of the new partnership as tailors capable of making a tailor-made suit to achieve the goals of the 2030 UN agenda.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – September was the month of waste. September was a record month, as 6.6 billion dollars were recorded in September. 5.7 Billion in ports, docks and breakwaters. All fell into the water. 780 Million disappeared in Moldova and 129 million went up in smoke in the Palestinian territories.  Mr President, at the same time in September, the Dutch Government is in the process of freeing up EUR 50 million for the care of the chronically ill and next year in the Netherlands the health insurance premium will increase by 10 euros. Mr President, I see it this way: a mother saves every euro and puts it together to pay for her daughter's school trip, while at the same time two blocks away, a mother throws 300 euros into a gambling machine. You can't do that. That's outrageous. Mr President, that is scandalous!

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). Madam President, the partnership agreements between the European Union and the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States must focus on three key issues. The first is the economic partnership with the primary aim of promoting the interests of the Member States of the Union, but also of creating sustainable development in these countries as a key factor in preventing illegal immigration. Secondly, creating conditions so that, especially for African countries, any criminal act of terrorism and violation of human rights and the rule of law automatically constitutes the application of measures and sanctions against those countries. Thirdly and most importantly, each entry in the budget of European Development Fund funds should set out clear guarantees, legal clauses and workable objectives directly linked to the continuation or interruption of the financing of these countries.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. I would like to congratulate Norbert Neuser on this difficult report on the future ACP-European Union relations.  As the experience of recent years has shown, thanks to the Cotonou Agreement, acp-European Union cooperation to come to this end has produced positive results. However, their dimension is still not satisfactory. There is a noticeable need for further cooperation and even strengthening it, especially from an economic point of point of time. Indeed, 80% of the ACP countries are still among the least developed countries.  This and the current economic situation indicate that a change in the formula in ACP-European Union relations is needed. The EU's commitment should increasingly be to develop relationships that are more partnerships.  Economic agreements and investment should play a key role in further development, which will also contribute to the greater empowerment of the ACP States. Trade is one of the three main pillars of the Cotonou Agreement, which increases investment, reduces unemployment and, of course, fights poverty. Strengthening it is therefore essential for the further growth and economic development of these countries.  Meanwhile, EU imports from West African countries only decreased from more than 38 billion in 2013 to just over 27 billion in 2015. At the same time, the EU remains the ACP countries' main trading partner with more than 5% of eu-wide imports and exports.  At the same time, the fight against poverty must be ensured in conjunction with progress towards the development of democracy and respect for human rights.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the EU-ACP cooperation framework has made a major contribution over the last forty years to strengthening the links between the peoples and parliaments of their respective countries. As the Cotonou Agreement expires, our cooperation must be dated and calibrated to the new millennium challenges.  We therefore need a new structure that preserves the parts of the EU-ACP acquis and preserves its essential elements. Human rights, gender equality, democratic principles and the rule of law must form the basis of values of this new agreement, together with good governance. Political dialogue must remain a central legal pillar. Articles 8 and 96 must also be more closely watched in order to preserve crises and conflicts, as Mr Sybroucke pointed out. Mr Neuser. I also call for the parliamentary dimension to be strengthened, but also for civil society to be involved.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. The forth coming to an end of the Partnership Agreement between the Union and a group of African, Caribbean and Pacific countries did not produce the expected results if compared with other Partnerships of the Union. Unfortunately m.in achievements in the fight against poverty, the construction of the rule of law or integration into the world economy are still not enough to assess the legacy of this agreement very well at this stage. I am particularly concerned that the dialogue on the promotion of human rights is un advanced and has significant differences of interpretation between some countries, leading to disputes and growing mistrust on the part of the ACP States. The imposition of EU solutions and the threat of withholding financial support are often interpreted by our partners as a manifestation of paternalism and even neocolonialism. Unfortunately, this does not help to build a viable partnership, on the contrary, it strengthens the donor-beneficiary relationship from which the Union must start to move away in order to build a partnership of equal actors based on common objectives: accountability, equal rights and cost-sharing.  I very much hope that when planning the directions and principles of cooperation, we will take into account differences of interest and take into account the changes that have taken place in the global economy, in politics and within both groups.  Let us examine in detail so far.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: Madam President, EU-ACP relations are far from out of date. On the contrary, the EU-ACP partnership has always been able to evolve in changing contexts, as many evaluations confirm. Significant progress has been made in the areas of health, promotion and regional cooperation in Africa, not to mention infrastructure. In terms of political cooperation, the record is a little more mixed. Indeed, this dimension is still largely unused. I still believe that the Doha Round, for example, which sought to combine trade and development for the benefit of all, and especially the weakest, failed because it could not agree on a common line between the Union and the 79 ACP states. From my point of view, it would be in the interest of both sides to agree on a strategic pact that could weigh heavily on the United Nations Assembly and the major multilateral conferences. But we must first ask ourselves how to value these potentials. However, it is clear that, unfortunately, our politicians - the Member States - are only weakly involved in this cooperation. As we keep proclaiming all day long that Africa's awakening is imminent, we would be entitled to expect more offensive, robust, determined and effective political action. Yes, we are forming a community of destiny in areas as diverse as climate, energy and security, and more specifically with our neighbours in sub-Saharan Africa. My last point is a warning to those who might be tempted to break up the EU-ACP relationship in its regional components. And I would not like to end without thanking Norbert Neuser for opening the debate with a report that is not the end of a process, but is only the beginning.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, relations between the European Union and the ACP countries must be based on the recognition of a historic debt for repairing hundreds of years of colonialism, loot, oppression and exploitation; in the recognition and combating the deeply asymmetric nature of north-south interdependencies that in recent years have not mitigated.  The objective of the gradual integration of acp countries into the world economy cannot ignore the non-integration that such integration should not be, but is, subordinate, dependent and peripheral integration based on unfair relations between unequal parts.  The liberalisation and deregulation of trade of which the so-called Economic Partnership Agreements are an instrument serve the interests of the powers and economic groups of the north, but not the sustainable development needs of the countries and communities of the south, quite the contrary.  The relationship with the ACP countries must be respectful of their sovereignty, their legitimate choices and aspirations, not a screen for imposing on them models of political and economic organisation or geostrategic alignment with the priorities and options of the European Union.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I have had the opportunity to participate in the ACP delegation since 2014 when I entered this House, and I would like to point out that I think that this political dialogue between our countries is very valuable, and that cooperation is positive.  Having said that, however, I do not mean that we should have been in such a hurry, as we have had in this House, to come up with a report on this at the moment. As my colleague Maria has mentioned in the past, I believe that we need to look at and study the issue much, much more carefully.  It is the case that, in addition to the ACP work, we have many other parallel structures, many of which also cover basically the same regions, and then we have to ask ourselves whether we are working properly. Having these parallel structures is also perceived as very messy by actors outside, but we must also ensure that, in the event of change, we must also ensure that what is good in the current structure and cooperation does not disappear. I am thinking in particular of the opportunities we have to talk together with several regions about issues that involve all of us, but not only these regions, but also other parts of the world. Climate change is one of those things that we need to discuss very broadly, including in this cooperation.

name: Raymond FINCH
text: – Madam President, I would first like to say how shameful it is that there appear to be more spectators in the gallery than there are Members in the Chamber. Is it any wonder that the peoples of Europe do not listen to you, when you cannot even be bothered to listen to yourselves? The EU-ACP partnership is based upon near—colonialism. The EU taxpayer will pay EUR 30 billion for the EDF in 2014-2020 in order to ensure that the poorer nations are in its debt and therefore subject to the rapacious greed of big business. This is against all that your European Union is supposed to stand for, and we see the results in the economic partnership agreements, in the fisheries agreements and in the common agricultural policy. If the EU really wants to help the third world, then it should enable those nations to build their own economies and ensure free trade, not just for raw materials in the age-old manner of the colonialists, but also for finished products and goods. As long as we keep pouring in aid for no good outcome, we encourage the cycle of third—world government dependency and keep the poorest the poorest. Democracy, independence and freedom come only when peoples have a safe, solid, sustainable economy. We need to break the cycle of dependency, and giving corrupt governments more and more taxpayers’ money merely encourages more of the same results.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the very notion of the community of development leads to the concept of borders and the regulation of the internal market. It is the Zollverein, it is the Community Europe which originally protected itself like any economic zone. My colleague de Sarnez's report pointed out, and rightly so, the need for an African internal market. I stress that it must be protected. It's that protection you refuse. But can we give development lessons with the failure of development at home and our approach to a borderless market, free and undistorted competition, an approach that has taken us where we are, namely, on the edge of the European economic precipice?  This approach, this ideological approach to the market, which destroys jobs at home, increases the North-South disparities in our country, but the Commission wants to impose it on Africa and other continents. It doesn't work. We want to move even further to the implosion of Europe and Africa. Not only is it destroying Europe's North-South development, the Commission also wants to destroy the North-South development of Europe's neighbour, that of Africa and the countries of southern Europe. Colleagues, we must say 'no' to these agreements. Developing countries are watching us.  The Lomé agreements dared protectionism for development. The Cotonou chords already opened up this crazy idea of the free fox in the free henhouse to obtain development. Countries refuse. It is blackmail at the opening of our borders, it is neocolonialism. Shame on the Commission, shame on us if we accept these agreements.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur, Mr Neuser, who has worked in a spirit of compromise, which has led to a balanced and ambitious text. This report represents an important contribution from Parliament which I hope will be taken into account in the communication we expect on the future of ACP-EU relations after 2020.  As the Permanent Rapporteur for Policy Consistency for Development (CPD), I am pleased to see that this concept has been highlighted in this report. The CPD has much to contribute, not only in revising the Cotonou agreement but also in the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals. That is why I wanted the report to once again call for the establishment of permanent co-staff on the CPD in the ACP-EU Joint Assembly.  It is true that the ACP-EU partnership has not fulfilled all its objectives and has disappointed in some respects, but I am convinced that we can improve these weaknesses while maintaining the current structure, which is a unique tool in the Union's external relations. Its legally binding nature contributes greatly to its effectiveness.  In my view, partnership reform must take into account our other foreign policy tools, including the various roadmaps that will lead to the Union's overall strategy. I regret that this strategy does not specifically mention the ACP-EU partnership. If there is one point on which the reform of the Cotonou agreement must focus all its efforts, it is that of strengthening political dialogue. Many African countries are currently facing serious political and electoral crises, the latest being Gabon, and, in particular, the question of the limits of presidential terms: this is where political dialogue makes sense. It must be able to be used by both sides to prevent these crises and act upstream.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, it really is time to renew our relations with the African, Caribbean and Pacific states, not only because the current Cotonou Agreement expires in 2020 but also because pressing challenges need solutions that we can only achieve jointly with our partner countries. I am strongly in favour of European Parliament support for a new cooperation structure keeping the unity of the European Union states with their 79 partner countries, under one umbrella, while at the same time permitting closer regional cooperation. Climate change is one of the issues that the EU and ACP countries have to tackle as soon as possible. Another is addressing poverty and the fragility of states, as the root causes of migration, in a sustainable way. This forum is the best place to listen to each other’s needs and find common solutions to global problems. Last but not least, allow me warmly to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Neuser.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Cotonou Partnership Agreement between the European Union and the members of the Group of African, Caribbean and Pacific States was signed in 2000. Over the past sixteen years, we have seen the states involved in the partnership and stakeholders fight to strengthen the three complementary pillars of the agreement – the political and economic dimension, trade cooperation and development cooperation – in order to eradicate poverty, promoting the ACP States in the world economy.  We welcome the results achieved so far. We regret, however, that the European Development Fund is a financial instrument outside the Union's general budget and we strongly demand that the European Parliament be able to play a stronger role in post-Cotonou decisions in the future. In some African countries there is growing tension due to political reasons. The increase in food and nutrition insecurity, drought and immigration is one of the issues facing the future Treaty. I also hope that youth integration will be seen as one of the key points to be resolved in the forthcoming agreements.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I think it is now the right time for us to debate the post-Cotonou period and have this report on the agenda. Thank you very much to Mr Neuser, who has made a great deal of effort in this and has also very well involved the political groups in this report. I think that the agreement should be an occasion for us to talk about the future in the area of better cooperation. Unfortunately, we have not achieved the objectives that we set ourselves in the four HYPERLINK 'https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lom%C3%A9-Abkommen' Lomé Agreements, which we set ourselves before Cotonou, namely to improve the living conditions of the people in the ACP sector.  For example, we have not managed to ensure that the African continent has really become part of the world economy in the form that local people benefit from it. We have not managed to that there is better governance, better governance, in large parts of the AKP, but we are still witnessing to this day – gabon has just been mentioned, I myself was in Zambia during the summer holidays for election observation – that there are political circumstances where it must be said that even in elections the beginning of illegitimateness comes about because the very circumstances are unfair, and therefore the people cannot get confidence in their leaders from the outset. I believe that we must start with: without good governance, there will be no lasting development. We must also question existing instruments. I would like to mention this general budget support, which has been a popular instrument for many years. I believe that we must find other ways of ensuring that the funds actually arrive where they should be used.

text: – Sinjura President, day hu rapport importanti għax jindirizza r-relazzjoni bejn il-pajjiżi tal-ACP at l-Unjoni Ewropea in jirrikonoxxi l-fatt li l-koperazzjoni bejn il-pajjiżi tal-ACP in l-Unjoni hi kisba valida in importanti, in ġiet imsaħħa matul is-snin. In prosit lir-Rapporteur Norber Neuser.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: – Madam President, first of all let me thank my colleague Mr Neuser for his good work. We have recognised that ACP-EU cooperation is a unique achievement. It has intensified the ties between ACP and EU countries for the last four decades. I would like to highlight two elements that would improve the situation of the peoples of the partner countries: first, placing the 2030 agenda and the sustainable development goals at the centre of the new agreements; and, second, placing the human—rights aspect at the centre of European action. Migration and displacement will dominate the ACP-EU agenda for the future. A new agreement must address this expanding challenge. To increase political oversight, we need a strong parliamentary dimension in the new cooperation agreement. We must guarantee that European development partnerships are concluded only with regimes respecting human dignity. Where governments cannot be our partners, we must bring on board local communities that are ready to cooperate with us. Faith-based communities and their organisations represent the real local power in very many places. They often manage development programmes that are already functioning well. Their efficiency on the ground is remarkable. My strongest message today is that we must engage better with local communities and faith-based organisations in coordinated – and I underline again coordinated – dialogue. Let me draw attention to the importance of local small and medium-sized  enterprises: they are key to the improvement of communities and the extension of social cohesion. Lastly, the situation is quite clear: let us have cooperation with local powers and international actors to address the humanitarian situation which can no longer be overlooked in many ACP countries.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Mr President, the EU-ACP framework represents a unique and privileged partnership between Europe and its partners in Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific. Sixteen years later, it's time to take stock. The sometimes too divergent characteristics between the different regions have led to the under-exploitation of the institutions of Cotonou. Yet they offer a unique opportunity for dialogue, exchange and cooperation between regions of the world that have so many challenges in common. It will therefore be essential, in my view, to review the framework for cooperation taking more account of the regional specificities of each party. It seems to me that we can work around four priorities. The first is that the future framework will have to put the sustainable development goals at the heart of its priorities, but also and above all the coherence of development policies to ensure that trade, migration, security and environmental policies are coherent and compatible with development objectives. The second priority is political dialogue. At a time when tensions are affecting much of Africa, it remains a fundamental pillar that has been used too little so far. This pillar will need to be strengthened and equipped with adequate tools to make it more efficient and relevant. The third priority is the economic pillar. In this regard, the European Union should commit itself to further supporting ACP countries in the implementation of the Economic Partnership Agreements (EPAs) when countries have decided to conclude them and to ensure that these countries have first strengthened their institutional capacities and their capacity for economic diversification and that they have reformed their tax policies before embarking on trade liberalization. Finally, the involvement of civil society must be guaranteed in all areas of cooperation, both in development and in trade cooperation, at all levels of dialogue and with new and more effective tools. Civil society must continue to be recognised as an official player in cooperation between the EU and the ACP countries.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, 80% of the world's least developed and most forgotten countries are in what we know here as ACP countries. And now that so much is being talked about the failures of the European Union, and now that so much is being said about the need to work on the causes of migration, we must at least show the peace of mind that we Europeans have long understood what needed to be done and got to work. We didn't start yesterday. It is worth recalling here the Lomé agreements and the one at issue today, the Cotonou Agreement, which remains a valid instrument, much more specific in development cooperation objectives than the Union's overall strategy or the United Nations 2030 Agenda, for example, both in promoting regional integration and in actions against climate change , one of the issues on which we have reached a common position. However, it is also true that, as of today, we have outstanding issues, challenges to overcome, new paradigms in the Union's relations with the ACP countries or the relations of these same countries with other global actors, such as China. We believe that, in essence, the model of collaboration based on both the political dimension, development strategies and economic and trade cooperation remains valid. Precisely, the coincidence at the time of the expiry of the Cotonou Agreement and the Union's multiannual financial framework gives us a unique opportunity to integrate the European Development Fund into the general budget and thus improve in transparency, efficiency and accountability. We know that political dialogue has failed to make improvements in human rights and democracy in countries that do not share the values of the Union: another challenge to overcome. From this house we must ensure that the work done in the twenty years has been consolidated and improved in the future. There's more than three years left, there's room. That is why I will support Mr Neuser's report, which I think is appropriate, well worked and which I take the opportunity to thank.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: – We are talking about the European Union's relations with the largest group of countries in the world. We have an enormous lot of important work to do that Brexit will not, if it happens, financially. Relations and cooperation between the ACP and the European Union to date have been and remain aimed at strengthening universal values and objectives such as the promotion of human rights, democracy and sustainable development. The agreement was concluded in Coutonou in 2000 and revised twice. In the years following the last audit, the development has shown, as demonstrated by my experience on the ground, with the conduct of two European Election Observation Missions in support of democracy in Nigeria and Kenya, that the starting points that we share with our ACP partners must be condensed through more specific regional strategies and regional agreements that take greater account of the changed political, economic and security situation. On the other hand, I very much agree with the report's emphasis that cooperation should take place in areas of common interest where mutual benefit could be expected, not only from an economic point of view, but also, and above all, with regard to peace and security, human rights, the rule of law, good governance, democracy, migration, the environment and so on. Peace is a value that, in my view, remains the first development priority. We cannot successfully tackle poverty unless peace is guaranteed. I therefore find it sensible that the ACP and the European Union work together as a whole, on this and other supporting values. In this context, I propose that, in the future, we devote even more energy to intercultural dialogue, which is still an underestimated potential for added value in polarised societies, which need a higher level of internal co-sim for a more sustainable development. I am grateful to my colleague Neusler and the shadow rapporteurs for their good work.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE). Mr President, I believe that if we really believe that the European Union should not be introverted, but should reach out to help - with a social face, with a social character and with an imaginative development policy - other countries outside the European Union, then we should support agreements such as the Koton agreement, the agreement with the Caribbean countries. , Africa and the Pacific, where the European Union really contributes, both economically, and in other ways... (The President interrupts the speaker for lack of English interpretation, which then takes the floor again) , then we should also consider that the agreement reached between the Caribbean, Pacific and African countries and the Member States of the European Union is the culmination of a modern European Union that responds to the calls of the whole of humanity and is everywhere where there is a problem. I believe that if one studies this agreement, in the sixteen years of its existence, one will realise that, no matter how many problems there are, no matter how many difficulties and obstacles arise, that it is a very useful agreement, useful because it really offers these countries and contributes both to sustainable development and to their development and integration into the world economy.  But I agree - and as shadow rapporteur in the opinion of the Committee on Budgets I supported this view with all my might - that the timing of the revision of the multiannual financial framework in 2020 and the expiry of the agreement offers us an important opportunity to integrate the budget of the European Development Fund into the Budget of the European Union, so that there is more effective management with transparency and with all those conditions required.  Mr President, I would like to stress one last thing, that it is indeed very important to have effective control and transparency where the European Union's money goes and that the principles of democracy, human rights and the rule of law must be applied in these countries.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We have 40 years of cooperation behind us, and only four years to prepare new conditions, new agreements, new rules for implementing cooperation between the Member States of the European Union and the 78 ACP States.  It is therefore necessary to draw lessons from the past, and these conclusions are that not all objectives have been achieved optimally. So that future years of cooperation – there is nothing to hide – also the concepts of aid are not in vain, action must be taken that is more effective. There is no doubt that, among other things, investment must be increased, not just trade and mere aid. The principle of fish needs to be replaced and replaced with the principle of fishing.  Unfortunately, we live in a time that is dangerous for such agreements, because we live in a time when they are building up forces against international trade agreements, and this is one of the very important elements of this agreement. This is a process that is dangerous for developing countries, and we must also take this into account in order to help these countries.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Cotonou Agreement is a good platform for cooperation between the European Union and the ACP countries. It is so because of the considerable number of countries that take part in it, but also because of the valuable links established between their peoples. However, little has been achieved in terms of poverty eradication and the integration of acp countries into the world economy. The 2030 Agenda and the Sustainable Development Goals must mark the high road to closer cooperation that takes into account the challenges that have occurred in the meantime.  The need to ensure, in the post-2020 period, greater relevance to the issue of human rights and the strengthening of political dialogue is, for example, an issue that cannot be underestimated. Just as it is essential to establish, within a legally binding common framework, sound monitoring mechanisms to safeguard the concrete implementation of the agreement. The new cooperation agreement will have to reflect an ambitious political project and make good governance a cornerstone, leaving behind the deleterious donor-beneficiary mentality.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the Cotton Agreement is a partnership agreement between the European Union and the countries of Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific, which, like any economic partnership agreement, is presented as a supposed opportunity to promote regional integration, trade and development, when in fact all it promotes is the interests of large companies at the expense of small businesses. , but also the peoples of the Contracting Parties. At the same time, the agricultural, environmental and social sectors are irreparably affected.  As an example, I mention the European Union-Southern Africa agreement, an agreement that leaves feta cheese and Kalamata olives, two Products of Designation of Origin important to Greece, off the Union's protection list, at a time when the production of oranges and lemons in Greece is expected to be affected by this agreement, since it removes tariff barriers to trade between Africa and the European Union. I therefore believe that all these agreements achieve is to harm national productions and increase social inequalities.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Mr. President, Dear Mr. Commissioner, I cannot imagine at all that the EU does not have an agreement with ACP countries after 2020. The 2000 Cotonu Agreement is, of course, a paper that is a bit outdated and today seeks new visions, new proposals and new relationships.  However, objectively, we need a global framework because with these countries we solve the key problems of this planet. We'll talk about poverty later and how to eradicate it. Most poor people live precisely in AKP countries, not to mention the migration problem we talk about all the time. Of course I'm partial to what they say: "Let's give someone a hook, not a fish." Let's help ACP countries develop their own economy on the principles of sustainable development and thus resolve the crisis we are facing.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, the partnership between the EU and ACP countries is an important vehicle for sustainable development and I would like to thank my colleagues who truly understand this. We all know that the future belongs to young people and that is why it is important for me to highlight the participation and empowerment of children and young people when we talk about the future of ACP-EU relations and sustainability. Article 26 of the Cotonou Agreement stipulates that our cooperation must support youth, releasing their potential. I would like to see such a commitment strengthened post 2020, with ambitious new initiatives and monitoring structures. We need to share best practice and empower civil society networks like the ACP Young Professionals Network, with whom I have had the great pleasure of working.

name: Julie WARD
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am thankful for this fruitful debate and interesting exchange. The comments I have heard demonstrate that we all agree that the European Union and its partner countries should engage in a relationship of equals. The donor—recipient mentality is over. The European Union has much to gain from building a strong alliance for the future. Let me reiterate support for the report presented today. Its vision of the future makes me confident about the next steps in the process. The Commission and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy have been preparing a joint communication for November, proposing broad elements and building blocks for a future policy framework with the ACP countries. It will be accompanied by an impact assessment of options for a Cotonou successor framework. This report and subsequent discussion in Parliament and the Council, as well as with the ACP leaders, will feed into the preparation of the recommendation to Council, with draft negotiating directives, in the course of 2017. Much is still to be decided, but I believe we are moving together in the right direction and for the benefit of all. I look forward to continuing our strong and fruitful cooperation as we go forward.

name: Norbert NEUSER
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Thank you again for the clear word: Donor mentality is over, and the new sequel program to Cotonou must also come from the spirit. I would also like to thank the shadow rapporteurs, because the cooperation has been very fruitful and also to bring forward a good report to the DEVE secretariat, in particular Jesper Haglund and his team, which has helped with great competence.  The AFET, INTA and BUDG committees support this report, and it is important that we have also involved these three important committees.  We have not yet discussed how the ACP countries will stand for a successor agreement, and I think these are the signals from our ACP partners: they want to maintain these developed relations. It is a very important argument to know what the partners want and to what extent the partners want to continue their work with us, the EU, beyond 2020.  We talked about new challenges. Let me take just one example: the fight against the causes of flight. Where do we have the opportunity to have a dialogue on the causes of flight, if not with the ACP. As members of Sudan, South Sudan, Ethiopia, Eritrea, Nigeria, Niger, Chad and Somalia, we have examples there that make it clear how important cooperation is and that we can also have political dialogue there and that we can also achieve results there.  Finally, if the US, Russia or China had such a treaty with 78 countries – grown over decades – they would lick their fingers and do everything they could to keep this treaty going!

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 4 October 2016. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – In order to promote sustainable development and democracy in the world, the European Union must consider how to develop relations with the ACP countries not only for the next few years, but also after 2020. The Cotonou Agreement, which has governed those relations so far, has proved to be an insufficient tool in that regard. I believe that the future partnership, if it is to be effective, must break with the donor-recipient mentality, above all taking into account the real needs of the ACP states. It must therefore be based more than ever on the involvement of national parliaments, local authorities, civil society and the private sector from the ACP countries. A good step in this direction was the extensive public consultation carried out by the European Commission with citizens and various social organisations around the world. I also believe that, in order to avoid duplication of certain tasks by the EU, it is important to bear in mind economic partnership agreements, which, as an important forum for regional cooperation, should remain the cornerstone of the future partnership.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission Declaration on Access to Education for Syrian Children in Lebanon (2016/2913(RSP)).

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by underlining our 100% commitment to the goal of education for all Syrian refugees, in line with our pledge at the Syria Donors Conference in London.  It is absolutely essential that we do not lose a generation of displaced Syrian children. First and foremost, this is important for the well—being of the children themselves. It is also crucial for regional stability, for the eventual recovery of Syria from this crisis as well as – let’s face it – in our own interest over the long term. Where there are needs, we are responding and we are ready, if necessary, to do more. Our neighbours in the region need to know that we stand by them as they work towards a better future. One of the outcomes of the London Conference was a joint commitment to provide access to quality education for all refugee and vulnerable children in host communities. We will make every effort to empower young Syrians by investing in their future. Education is, and has always been, a key priority of the EU response to the crisis in Syria. So far we have made a substantial contribution to education in Lebanon, with EUR 180 million allocated to this sector since the beginning of the crisis. We have stepped up this approach both through the EU Trust Fund in response to the Syria crisis as well as the compact we have been negotiating with the Lebanese and Jordanian authorities. This aims to turn the challenges posed by the huge influx of Syrian refugees into an opportunity both for refugees and host communities. In Lebanon the focus has been on education, where we hope that reforms will have an impact across the entire public education sector.  EUR 42.5 million has already been allocated to the so-called Reaching All Children with Education Strategy, the abbreviation for which is RACE, which I think is a good one. Called the RACE Programme, it was designed by the Lebanese Ministry of Education. A substantial part of this has gone towards the enrolment of Syrian children in formal and non-formal education, the supply of educational material and transport. I am pleased to say that this coming school year is already well funded and we will be able to cover school fees for over 168 000 Syrian children in formal education. I must stress, however, that money alone will not solve the problem of access to education. There are still serious legal, administrative and technical barriers. This includes the lack of residency status, the distance between where refugees live and the schools that service them but also, unfortunately, harassment and discrimination, which has been documented in last summer’s Human Rights Watch report.  The problem of residency status is a serious one and has a clear impact on freedom of movement of refugees and leads to exploitation, including child labour. This is why we have placed this at the core of the EU-Lebanon compact. In exchange for the considerable financial support being offered by the European Union, Lebanon has agreed to provide an appropriate and safe environment for refugees. We are working closely with various UN agencies and international NGOs in this respect and it should be noted that when we see or hear of the commendable work being done by UNICEF, UNHCR and others, that behind this effort there is a strong European Union contribution which should also be acknowledged.  Although not directly linked with the subject we are dealing with today, I should also mention the humanitarian initiative launched by my colleagues Mogherini and Stylianides over the past few days. The tragedy of Aleppo cannot continue and we call on all parties concerned to ensure that the desperately needed aid can be delivered. Thank you for your attention and I await a very fruitful discussion.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. We visited the Committee on Civil Liberties in Lebanon a week and a half ago and we have seen on the ground that EU support for the country is really crucial. Support to help Lebanon deal with the more than one million refugees from Syria who have sought refuge in the small neighbouring country. 489 000 Children between the age of 3 and 18 from Syria are in Lebanon. It is also our responsibility to ensure that they can also go to school. It is quite right what the Commissioner said: not only Syrian children but also, please, keep an eye out for other vulnerable children, such as those of the local Lebanese population, but also those of palestinian refugees.  With regard to Syrian refugees, many of these children have been sharing or sometimes missing entire school years because of the circumstances, and that requires a tailored approach to ensure that these children do not end up being the child of the bill. Such an approach costs money and we have seen on the ground that the support from the European Union is greatly appreciated and works.  However, it is about more than just money and I am very pleased that the Commissioner made the comment on the residence papers. More and more Syrian refugees in Lebanon are struggling to renew their residence papers. At the moment, around 70% of people do not have the right papers and this also has consequences for the children. Some parents are afraid to take their children to school because they are afraid of being checked for those papers. So I also ask the European Commission: continue to consult with the Lebanese Government - very keenly - so that we really try to get these children to school in this way. The European aid budget to Lebanon is working. It's tangible. People notice it in their own daily lives, so let's make sure that we continue to do that, that we may broaden it, because as long as 100,000 Syrian children in Lebanon are still not going to school, our work is not over.

name: Norbert NEUSER
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has We must ensure that the commitments made at the donors' conference for Syria are implemented. Commissioner, you said that it is about the well-being of children, it is about building a Syria after the civil war. But it is also a question of avoiding further causes for the flight from the camps to Europe. We were in the camps in Turkey a year ago. We have been told that we young families are leaving Turkey because we do not have the opportunity here for our children to be integrated into education, into school. This example makes it clear that we have an enormous amount of work to do here. We have 250 000 out of 500 000 children who do not have access to school, and that is why we must do everything we can to support Lebanon so that Syrian children have access to education. With its EDUCA campaign, the S&D Group intends to do just that and therefore wants the budget to be enlarged accordingly. In the near future, we are in the process of looking specifically at the situation in the education system as part of a fact-finding mission in Lebanon. Any child who has the opportunity to go to school there in Lebanon in order to later rebuild his country for himself, for his own good, but also for the Syrian community, is very important. Thank you very much, and I hope that we can put so much pressure on donors in particular that the necessary money for the coming school year will also be made available quickly.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa In recent days, I have been in two more Countries in the Middle East: Lebanon and Jordan. I visited refugee camps there, just like I did a few months ago when I was in Iraq. However, as I would like to emphasise, the situation of Syrian children and young people in Lebanon is particularly difficult. My PPE colleague also talked about refugees from Palestine, but they have their own self-government, for example, they have their own law enforcement, and this is a community that has been operating in Lebanon for decades.  The degree of colonization of Palestinian children is much greater than that of Syrian children and young people. Of course, we in this House can differ on many issues when it comes to migrants, the influx of immigrants into Europe, their separation. However, I think we are no different in terms of the fact that we need to make it worthwhile and we need to invest precisely in the refugees who live there, as well as in their education. The more refugee children are educated, the less likely they are to enter the path of terrorism, which, although it is also, of course, a temptation for educated people, is very common among the uneducated.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, thank you very much to all the members of the Commission present. Some of us came from Lebanon a few days ago and we could see, on the one hand, that the Lebanese authorities saw as a very, very difficult burden to cope with the situation of refugees in their country— to which, by the way, because they are not obliged, they are practically not given legal roles. Indeed, increasingly, Lebanese society is talking about sending them to Syria; and they talk about safe places, which we know doesn't exist.  And indeed, UNHCR and Unicef work extraordinarily, and you are talking about 168,000 schoolchildren in this school year, but there are more than 250,000 who are out of school, and we cannot settle for less than everyone has opportunities for schooling.  In this case, efficiency is not something we have to pursue, but we have to achieve. Because six years of lost schooling is practically a creature's life, and we're talking about elementary school, high school.
