And only a very small handful, a handful of young people with enough schooling have been able to access the university, all the Syrian refugees who are of age and who are studying, because Syrians had the highest graduation rate in the whole region. And we're talking about people like you and me who six years ago started to miss opportunities, and who also know that their parents, their cousins, their older siblings had opportunities for schooling before the war that plagued them.  Therefore, Commissioner, we can only make schooling 100 per cent and reach 100 per cent. We can't keep those 168,000 and congratulate ourselves on that.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, the international response to the war in Syria has been and remains dire. No one seems to have any real interest in ending this massacre. And the worst consequences always fall on the most vulnerable: children. Lebanon, which can give us lessons in compliance with international legality with respect to refugees, grants the right to schooling for Syrian children. However, the support of the European Commission and the Member States for refugee education is still very poor and secondary. And it's not because of a lack of resources, but a matter of priorities. Because we do have seven billion euros to give Turkey to do the dirty work, but we are not able to guarantee a human right, such as public and quality education to each and every refugee, financially supporting Lebanon. There are two ways to respond to this so scary migration crisis for some of you. One, with fences and external borders, and, another, seeking a dignified and secure future in conflict zones. If we do not guarantee a future to children suffering from war, we will be paving the way for hatred, fear and therefore fascism.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I would like to begin by recalling the very great responsibility that Lebanon has taken for the Syrian refugees ever since the war started. I would have been proud if the countries of Europe had taken the same responsibility, if we had also given the refugees a residence permit and work permit, given the children schooling, etc., etc.  When 163,000 refugees arrived in Sweden last year, our reception system collapsed. Housing, schools and health care were not enough. Nevertheless, we are one of the countries that received; not everyone does. I fully understand that Lebanon has the same problem, but their problems are so much greater. I also understand whether Lebanon thinks we should take more responsibility.  In order to avoid being accepted into Europe, we are talking about us helping out on the ground, and that is where the money comes into it. Although we have promised a lot of money, great resources, not all those resources are in place. According to the study to which the Commissioner referred, i believe only 23% had arrived.  At the same time, we also want lebanon to give a residence permit and work permit when refugees come to Lebanon, they should give their children school, etc., and we want to help. But we're going to look at what we do ourselves. We're not actually doing the same thing ourselves. We should also make demands on ourselves.  The Commissioner also raised the problem of losing his residence permit. When you are without a residence permit, you become undocumented, and when you are undocumented, you dare not let your children go to school because you are afraid that the authorities will find one; you can search for the parents by knowing where the children are. This is a problem that we have not only in Lebanon, but also in countries here in Europe. It's hard to be undocumented no matter where in the world you live. But the important thing about this is to make sure that we do not get these lost generations, perhaps, of refugee children, which the Commissioner was talking about. Not being able to go to school, which may be the only fixed point in life, also leads in the long term to major health problems for those children, and we must avoid that at all costs.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Mr President, today we cannot stay silent and turn our back on the bloodshed in Aleppo. Children are being slaughtered, injured and starved. They are trapped and traumatised. More than 100 kids have been killed in Aleppo last week by the Syrian army and Russian air strikes. More than 100 000 children are under siege. We have to strongly condemn the indiscriminate bombing of families and hospitals and the use of illegal weapons. The United Nations Secretary calls it war crimes. So what can we do?  The EU should call for an immediate ceasefire, and I welcome the new humanitarian initiative for Aleppo to ensure access to emergency aid, safe passage for rescue workers and the evacuation of the sick and the wounded. The EU must also relaunch negotiations. There is no military solution. The EU should unite in confronting Russia with its responsibility as a member of the United Nations Security Council. For Russia to be a partner for peace, they must respect humanitarian law and go back to the negotiating table, and those responsible must be held accountable.  All Member States should increase resettlement for thousands of kids, especially unaccompanied minors, and education. Going back to school gives children a sense of normality, a chance for self-sufficiency, and hope for the future. Education empowers children, it helps prevent violence, early marriage, forced labour and radicalisation and recruitment. With the Intergroup of human rights in the European Parliament that I co-chair, we stand united with the children of Syria. We fully support the ECHO/UNICEF Emergency Lessons campaign to provide education for children in conflict, and the No Lost Generation initiative to recruit Syrian teachers for Syrian children. We fully support the UNICEF campaign Education Cannot Wait as five years is a lifetime. We urge the EU and the Member States to increase efficient funding for education for Syrian children. Let us raise our voices and invest in children. End violence against the children of Syria.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, no one suffers more in war situations than children. They are victims of bombing, they are victims of displacement, they lose their access to education; sometimes they lose touch with their own families.  When a war lasts six years, or longer, as is the case in Syria, what is at risk is the entire life cycle of these lost children in different places, many of them in refugee camps.  Lebanon, to some extent, is an example. It assumes a number of refugees who, if we were even one-tenth generous, would not currently have any problems in the European Union. We cannot therefore blame Lebanon, but it is true that Lebanon has to solve problems such as those regarding legal residence, work permits and the effective schooling of 250,000 children who do not yet have access to its classrooms.  Nothing provides more opportunities for children's future lives than peace and education. And nothing provides more stability to societies than education for peace. Therefore, let us make our efforts to provide stability, peace— ending this conflict— and educating these children to have a future life in reconstruction.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Lebanon, like Jordan, is where refugees really are, people who have fled the war and are waiting for it to end in a neighbouring country. They really need a house, or a room, because peace is a house. Let us all consider what we have done to make this unnecessary war end, but while it continues, they need to be helped there on the ground. And Poland is a country that not only speaks, but simply helps. We, two months ago, increased spending on aid for refugees in Lebanon, on the maintenance of schools, transferred to NGOs that help people there on the ground, but above all these people have to go home. I listen with great concern to these opinions in this House, we dream: war will end, punishment, prosecution of the guilty and so on. How many people will live to this unconditional surrender? This war really lasts many years too long.

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the conflict in Syria is producing a lost generation of millions of children who have never been in class or who have only memories of such experience. In Lebanon, the Government, together with several organisations and through programmes such as Unicef's EU-funded No Lost Generation, does active work to enable minors to access public education, health, nutrition and hygiene services. Unfortunately, most children remain out of school. In Lebanon, figures say 150,000 Syrian children do not go to school, and it is estimated that by the end of the year the number will reach 400,000. We are facing a challenge that is not just humanitarian. We can and must continue to fund these programmes to ensure a basic education for an entire generation who will one day return to their country and be responsible for their reconstruction. But do we really think that might be enough? We must have political courage. First, our diplomacy has to fight for a peaceful solution to the Syrian war, starting with a ban on arms sales; secondly, it is useless and shameful to sign agreements with third countries to take care of refugees arriving at our borders. If we fail to achieve this political effort, which is sustainable if we divide it among all Member States, the humanitarian will be of little use.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: – Mr President, Syrian girls and children were not brought by a hurricane-force wind to Lebanon. They fled because of a war of destabilization that many countries in the European Union— and above all our dear allies — finance and in which they train and propel extremist groups that practice terrorism. Syria had a strong education system: nearly 100% of children in primary school; 70% in high school. Lebanon shows the shames of the European Union. A country of just 4.6 million is hosting 2 million Syrian refugees. A country with a precarious balance that makes an admirable effort to school 60% of Syrian girls and boys from six to eleven years old. Since we do not comply with refugees—which shames us—we need to support this effort more. But above all, peace must be pushed forward between the legitimate government and the non-terrorist opposition, because that is the only solution for Syrian girls and boys to be able to re-study their country.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: – Mr President, Jordan and Lebanon have been humane and responsible in their approach to the refugee crisis. These two countries have taken in more than four million refugees in total, more than a third of their total population. Lebanon hosts more than one million Syrian refugees. Lebanon has 417,000 Syrian refugee children aged three to 14. It is estimated that almost half of them do not have access to any form of education.  Between 2012 and 2015, the European Commission provided 269 million for humanitarian aid in Lebanon in connection with the Syrian crisis. In 2016, the European Commission plans to allocate 87 million additional funds for humanitarian assistance. I appreciate this effort by the European Union.  Education is the future, it means hope. But mothers of children who have not had a chance to get to Lebanon ask themselves a different question every day. Will my baby be alive tomorrow? Will he survive another attack by Russian and Assad forces?  I remind you, ladies and gentlemen, that this Saturday was the third time a trauma hospital has been bombed in Alep, where there are also child patients. Jordan and Lebanon deserve not only our recognition, but also continued financial support under the European Union Regional Fund and European Humanitarian Aid. The least we can do is make it easier for those who save lives instead of us. Let's stop the killing of Syrian children by the Assad-Russian alliance. Let's give Syrian children an education. That's the best weapon against war.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – Prejšnji teden sem se vrnila iz Libanona, kjer si štiri milijone Libanoncev deli državo s skoraj poldrugim milijonom beguncev. Med begunci v Libanonu je danes še vedno četrtina Palestincev, ki so že drugo ali tretjo generacijo brez državljanstva. Ostali so večinoma iz Sirije. Več kot polovica vseh je otrok, med njimi tretjina šoloobveznih, a jih v šolo hodi le 30 odstotkov. Dovoljenja za prebivanja so predraga, vse več beguncev nima... (Govorka je nadaljevala v angleščini, ker ni bilo tolmačenja.) Mr President, I hear there is no interpretation. I will make it short in English. I just wanted to say that last week I came from Lebanon, and it was very shocking. A third of children are not going to school, and the reason is, for the most part, that they do not have residency permits. Residency permits cost USD 200 per year, and 90% of refugees today do not simply manage to get them. So their parents are extremely afraid to send their kids to school, not to mention that private schools are impossible to reach. The situation is very critical, economically and politically, because of the war in Syria. What is very worrying is the new policy of the Lebanese Government, which is urging us to recognise some parts of the country as safe, and send refugees back. I think this is completely unacceptable. I completely agree with my colleague: we have to ensure that the money gets there. But it is not only money that is crucial. It is extremely crucial that we create efficient policies on the ground so that – in a highly corrupt environment – money gets to where it is needed.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: – Mr President, when we listen to the public debate about refugees and asylum seekers in Europe, it would be easy to think that Europe is facing the main crisis, and it also sounds as if the deal or the statement with Turkey – as the unofficial and intransparent deal is now called – is the main solution.  This picture could not be more false, and it only distracts from the urgent need for the EU Member States to do their homework and ensure that our borders are protected and that they develop a common EU position to engage actively with the goal of facilitating a negotiated end to the horrifying war in Syria. As long as Assad’s and Russian planes are bombing residents and homes, people will not return.  Let there be no confusion: it is the Lebanese who have taken extraordinary numbers of people in need. It is the half a million Syrian children who live in an absolute crisis: half of them not enrolled in schools, and girls being particularly vulnerable. I have no illusions about the short- or long-term impact of a lost generation on these people themselves and also on us. We must connect the dots and realise that our fates are intertwined. If we prefer sheltering the region over opening our doors, we must invest in safe, sufficient and accessible education for kids in Lebanon. We cannot afford for Lebanon to destabilise, and it would cause more suffering for children.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8)

name: Marek JUREK
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – I would like to ask my colleague if she does not notice that the Russian intervention, which plays a very destructive role in Syria, is, however, much shorter than this war. We really do not think about how to continue this war, but to bring peace there as soon as possible, because it is the only rescue for these children and the only chance to return home for those hundreds of thousands of refugees who are in Jordan and Lebanon, and the only chance for the excuse to continue the immigration wave to Europe.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: blue-card answer. – I heard only a statement from my respected colleague. However, let me reiterate that, indeed, the Russians are playing a destructive, unacceptable role in bombing innocent people in Syria, and it is high time that the EU stopped allowing this to happen. It is in the vacuum that the EU and the international community have left that the destructive forces that are killing people have taken too much space. I think that we should be very focused on what we have to do ourselves, which is on the one hand to allow for a humane and functioning asylum policy – and that goes for all EU Member States – and on the other hand to invest in a common position and a more ambitious diplomatic approach to a negotiated peace in Syria.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Access to formal education is one of the most important aspects of the refugee crisis, and we have neglected this for far too long. I am pleased with this debate and with the progress that is evident. The situation is indeed appalling. During one of my visits to the camp, a young man, 14 or 15 years old, accompanied me, explained the situation to me, and I then asked him where he had learned English. His answer was: I found a dictionary and learn it by heart. I will never forget this young man's answer! And I ask you: isn't it a scandal that this man didn't have a chance to go to school? And what will become of him in a year, two or three years if he continues to be denied access to education?

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, education is a fundamental human right and essential for the exercise of all other human rights. That is why the Committee on Culture and Education has put forward the proposal of education corridors. I am very proud that my group, the Socialists and Democrats, have launched the EDUCA campaign, calling for more international funding to be focused on the education of refugee children and young people, and mobilising universities in Europe and in conflict zones to act on this.  A whole generation of refugee children, especially girls and young women, face a bleak future without education. This is also important for all the welcoming countries who will benefit from the economic contribution of educated newcomers. It is a moral humanitarian duty for the European Union, as one of the main welcoming regions and a key player in the international scene, to guarantee that these young people have the opportunity for a brighter future.   Education initiatives, including informal education, must support refugee children’s mental health after they have gone through traumatic experiences. It is vital for present and future conflict resolution and peace-building in the region.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, five years after the start of the conflict in Syria, more than 250 000 children – approximately half of the nearly 500 000 school—age Syrian children registered in Lebanon – are out of school. This is totally unacceptable. The high number of refugee children out of school is an immediate crisis.  Education is a fundamental right under international law. All children in Lebanon – including Syrian refugees – have a legal right to free and compulsory primary education and access to secondary education without discrimination. Education is also crucial for protecting children in situations of displacement, which can sometimes last for an entire childhood.  Despite these efforts, too many Syrian children are still out of school. I believe Lebanon needs more international financial support to respond to the educational needs of Syrian refugees, including expanding and rehabilitating public schools, investing in quality education, fully including children with disabilities, training and hiring more teachers and subsidising school transportation.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, around one million people urgently need humanitarian assistance in Lebanon, half of them being children. Lebanon is a country that is facing the humanitarian crisis that has hit it with enormous efforts – and it is perhaps doing so more courageously than Europe which, proportionally, as we all know, takes in far fewer refugees – and many of these efforts concern children. In Lebanon, Syrian children can go to school, but only on paper, because unfortunately Human Rights Watch describes to us a situation that is actually very difficult. More than half of Syria's 500 000 children are unable to access education and granting a right is not always the same as ensuring that they are practised. The extreme poverty of Syrian families and the difficulty of access to the world of work and having a residence all weigh on the future of these children who have already experienced the worst that this world could offer them.  Lebanon – but I believe it is Europe's moral duty – must give these children the opportunity to fight one day by the force of culture that enemy so ignorant that today forced them to leave their homes and their country.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too recently had the opportunity to participate, together with the Committee on Budgetary Control, in a mission to Lebanon and Jordan, visiting the very refugee camps where Syrian refugees live. The situation is dramatic and it is more dramatic than we can imagine, especially with regard to the conditions of children, not least because, if the estimates are correct, there will be around 250 000 children who will not have access to education and who will therefore be denied a fundamental right for their growth and, above all, for a dignified future. So many, perhaps too many, times in this House we have discussed the migration crisis and its terrible consequences, especially for children. The situation of children must now be put at the top of the European Union's political cooperation agenda. Only in this way will we be able to give real hope to children and avoid the phenomenon of the lost generation that the younger generations of Syrians are in danger of encountering. In this respect, I hope that support for educational programmes for Syrian children in Lebanon will be renewed.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Europe and refugees have the same interest in a returning refugees to their home countries as soon as the root causes are reduced or eliminated. So we need to eliminate the root causes and help where there is trouble, not bring it here. To this end, it is vital that people forced to flee can live in suitable living conditions in camps close to their home countries.  And one of the most important elements of this is education. Providing education is essential not only for the healthy development of the child, but also for the future of their own community. An entire generation cannot fall out of education, if only to avoid radicalisation. This is why it is very important that Syrian children are edien in Lebanon. And I am pleased that Hungary also directly supports the provision of education in refugee camps in Lebanon, Jordan and Iraq with concrete pledges or the construction of hospitals.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is an endless emergency for syrian refugees in Lebanon. According to a report by Human Rights Watch on the plight of Syrian children who are refugees in Lebanon, there are 250 000 children who have been denied access to education. Only 3% of children have attended a Lebanese public school in the last year. However, the Lebanese Government's efforts to ensure a minimum of education for Syrian children are insufficient. Public schools reject disabled children for lack of resources and many families with expired residence permits cannot send their children to school for fear of being arrested. Access to education is essential to help and give a future to this new generation, but also to overcome the signs of so much violence. International economic support for projects to expand the education programme is crucial, but concrete political actions are also needed to promote reception. The risk is that otherwise the hopes of the young Syrians trapped by the war in Lebanon will also remain in vain.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, Lebanon is a small country of 4.5 million people, currently home to over one million refugees, half of whom are children. Of these children, 250,000 do not have access to education. Efforts to provide assistance to Lebanon, but also to Jordan, must therefore be strengthened and related actions must be focused on the major issue of education, the lack of which undermines the future of these children.  In Greece, Commissioner, the refugee situation has reached the fore. Moreover, it is not possible to entrust the Greek education system that has been dismantled by the troika and with the education of thousands of refugee children. For this reason, Mr Hahn, the education of refugee children in Greece must be provided exclusively within the accommodation centres, with exclusive funding from the European Union. So instead of the Union giving EUR 6 billion to Turkey, where refugee children end up working in textile industries, it is better to give this money to accommodation structures in Lebanon, Jordan and Greece.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Mr. President, this discussion reminded me of the 90s in Croatia, of the war in the Balkans when many people were displaced, when many refugees came to Istria, a region where I then acted politically, when with many young people, elementary and high school students, we had serious problems with how to continue their educational cycle. Someone then lost a few months, maybe someone lost a year, but here we are talking about children losing more years. And it's really tragic. Remembering those days and knowing about problems in an organized country like Croatia – with a hundred problems, but an organized country – I can imagine what it can look like in Lebanon or Jordan.  I invite you, Mr. Commissioner, to make additional efforts, regardless of what you are very engaged in, to help these countries because they deserve our support.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). Mr President, when there are large movements of a migratory nature, the great and innocent victims of these developments are children who are suffering from suffering, such as lack of education. This is also the case with Syrian refugees in Lebanon. But this is happening, in an even worse form, also in Europe and in particular in Greece, which has been destroyed by the measures of the Memorandum and is therefore unable to absorb these millions of illegal immigrants who remain on its territory. Among these illegal immigrants there are many children. The education system cannot absorb them, but the incompetent and incapable Greek governments, instead of asking the European Union for help for these children, are trying to force them into Greek schools. What do I mean by force? I mean, when their parents complain because children are also at risk of disease, the government sends the order rehabilitation units to hit the Greeks. This is the problem that the European Union must face in my opinion and not so much the problem of Lebanon.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to express my outrage at the genocide of children that is taking place in Syria, where hospitals and innocent victims are not even respected. With regard to the right to education of children in Lebanon – I would remind you that Lebanon is hosting more refugees than the whole of Europe – I have to say that some time ago we launched the Educa campaign, and I am glad that the Commission has taken it up, and we have reached EUR 52 million more to overcome the meagre 2 % of humanitarian aid that currently went to educate children in these refugee or displacement situations.  I think it is also important to remember that, if we want to avoid a lost generation, we must make more efforts – as I also ask the Commission – to ensure that all the Member States to which we have sent an official request as the European Parliament's Committee on Culture and Education take on board the proposal of the educational corridors, that is to say, to open Up European and Euro-Mediterranean universities to children and students who risk losing the entire course of study.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is good for colleagues to remember the massacre in Aleppo, a massacre of children, and they are also right to recall the efforts being made by Lebanon, which alone is hosting more refugees than we received in Europe last year. The Human Rights Watch report, in July this year, says that more than half of the nearly 500,000 Syrian children registered in Lebanon are outside the school system. Some have been out since their arrival five years ago. Despite the efforts of the Lebanese Government and donors, the lack of resources and the restrictive residence requirements limit access to education and give them to the scourge of child labour. Education is a right and must be given priority in these contexts, as it ensures a guarantee of protection and a sense of normality for children, at the very moment when they are most vulnerable. Postponing educational activities until the emergency and the crisis are over means risking never returning to school, often condemning them to a future of poverty. Commissioner Stylianides had stated his intention to make the EU the first international donor to reach 4 % of expenditure on humanitarian aid for education in emergency situations. Well, starting with support for Lebanon, we need to do more.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it is good to see and to hear that there is, across all parties, a common understanding that we have to be extremely focused and committed to guaranteeing education for every child. It is also important to take care that those who are not yet in school have the opportunity to attend school. It is impossible, and I think there is a moral obligation, not to lose any generation, not to lose any child and to give everybody an opportunity to be educated. I think we are all impatient and we are all concerned because still, I agree, not every child is going to school. There are a lot of reasons for that and we should not underestimate that many families push, urge, force their children to work, to contribute to the family’s financial support and income. There are also reasons, as it was already said by some colleagues, because of the lack of having a residency status. This is why one of the key areas we have addressed in our negotiations with the Lebanese Government concerning an EU compact agreement is that this has to be resolved in order to guarantee, including from a legal perspective, the possibility to enrol in schools.  There is also some progress, I have to admit. There is now a decision by the Lebanese Government to apply the new Lebanese curriculum. There were some discussions in the past whether it should be the Syrian or the Lebanese curriculum, but there is now a decision, and I think it is a good decision to apply the Lebanese curriculum which allows also that Lebanese teachers can teach Syrian kids. There should also be an opportunity for Syrian teachers who are refugees to get a work permit to teach Syrian kids, and this is also something we have addressed in our negotiations concerning the compact. There was also an issue about the money. May I say that in 2016, as far as the expected number of school children being de facto in school is concerned, this is being financed. There is an overall budget of EUR 191 million. Out of that, EUR 190 million is provided by the European Union and its Member States, with more than 60% of this budget being provided by the European Union. Primarily the financing is provided via UNICEF, but we are also trying to find an agreement with the Lebanese Government directly. This also depends a little bit on the very complicated political situation inside Lebanon. As there is no president elected, with all the consequences of that, it is difficult to have an agreement with the Lebanese Government, and therefore we have decided, in order not to waste time and resources, to channel most of the money via UNICEF. There is one element I would like to highlight, and I think this is something we should not forget. Of course it is important to provide elementary and secondary school education, but it is equally important to offer afterwards children in the region vocational education. Therefore, also the aim of this new compact is to support the Lebanese economy to offer jobs, to offer economic business opportunities and to give young people the opportunity to get an apprenticeship, as an example.  So while this is about investment in young people, it is not only an investment in their basic education, but equally important is to have an investment further on in specific training and education to become a skilled member of the workforce. I think this is something which should be our joint focus in the future, of course still taking care about the elementary and secondary school education. Once again, I think we should be determined to provide this additional education not only in Lebanon but also, of course, in Jordan, in Turkey. Wherever Syrian refugee children are, we have to support them and their parents.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate has been closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Our priority objective in terms of helping refugee children, in addition to ensuring their safety and access to food and medical care, should be universal access to free education. Children's education is the best investment in the future. This is a long-term investment and the only one through which we can educate new generations in a spirit of peace, tolerance and intercultural understanding. The education of refugee children is also an opportunity for them to return to the normality and partial stability they enjoyed before the war. The school gives you a certain sense of security and can help you cope with difficult experiences. Through education, young people also acquire knowledge and skills that will help them find themselves in a new situation and allow them to develop further. Despite the unquestionable added value of education for the lives of future generations of migrants, it remains one of the most underfunded areas of aid. We cannot allow this! I thank the Commission for proposing a new humanitarian aid package for educational projects for children from crisis areas. I look hope for its rapid and efficient implementation. Every child deserves the chance to have a better life, which education can provide for them.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question on the overall objectives and commitments of the EU on nutrition and food security in the world, addressed to the Commission by Enrique Guerrero Salom, on behalf of the Committee on Development (O-000099/2016 - B8-0717/2016) (2016/2705(RSP)).

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: Author. – Mr President, Commissioner, I am intervening to present this oral question which the Committee on Development has an interest in discussing with the European Commission. In September last year, world leaders, encouraged and accompanied by civil society, including numerous non-governmental organizations, agreed on the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. The various points, specifically in the second, referred to, underlined that the fight against hunger and malnutrition is still a central issue today, as early as the 21st century. Working to end hunger, achieve food security, provide better nutrition, provide means for sustainable agriculture are, in today's world, still to be achieved. The Committee on Development, which is presenting this question for debate, would like to stress that part of our contribution to development has undoubtedly served to reduce the number of people suffering from malnutrition in the world, but it is far from having achieved the objectives of eradicating it from our reality. In fact, the proportion of malnourished people in developing regions has halved since 1990, but still 785 million people do not receive enough food and do not get the necessary nutrients either. Chronic malnutrition affects 160 million children, the cause of nearly half of deaths among children under the age of five, one in six being below weight for their ages. Inadequate nutrition during the first 1,000 days of life will have negative consequences on a child's physical and intellectual abilities throughout his or her life. That is why, in 2012, the World Health Assembly set a target of achieving a 40% reduction in the number of stunted children by 2025. We urge the Commission to increase efforts to combat malnutrition and that is why we need specific interventions in those first 1 000 days of life. I would like to recall that the European Union committed itself at the 2012 London Summit to reduce the stunting of at least seven million children by 2025 and to contribute EUR 3.5 billion by 2020 to this cause. We hoped that this year in Rio de Janeiro we would take stock of progress and renew our commitments. It wasn't possible. However, action is now more urgent than ever, because development interventions against malnutrition receive only 0.57% of all official development aid. We need to multiply the investment by 70 times to meet our goals. In 2013 the European Union committed 400 million for specific initiatives. We call on the Commission to increase this commitment to an additional 1 billion euros. We need to implement strategies, we and all of our partners, to support the important role that small-scale farmers play. They produce 70% of the world's food. We need to support them, use their potential, increase their yield and productivity, preserve the variety of seeds and the nutritional value of what they produce. Commissioner, I would like to hear what the Commission intends to do in this area. I'm sure you agree with us that we have to do a lot more. So has the President of the World Bank, who has even pointed out or said that we need to point out to the governments of countries that are not meeting their objectives. We also know what needs to be done in food security and we ask the Commission to tell us what it intends for the coming years. We would like to hear new initiatives and ask Member States to commit themselves in 2017 to an intergovernmental summit that reviews the objectives and takes stock of the needs ahead.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Committee on Development and its Chair, Ms Linda McAvan, for putting nutrition high on the development agenda in line with our commitment to the UN 2030 Agenda and Sustainable Development Goals. The resolution on malnutrition proposed by the committee is, in our view, an important step forward. Since 2012, the Commission has emerged as a world leader in the nutrition arena. This leadership is backed by a robust policy framework addressing both stunting and wasting. Over the last three years, we have observed a trend pointing towards the decrease of stunting. Our first progress report on the European Commission’s Nutrition Action Plan shows that we are well on track to reach the commitment of reducing the number of stunted children under the age of five by seven million by 2025.  Our further actions on nutrition and food security should be guided by the approach that would seek to strike the right balance between our preferred nutrition-sensitive interventions that address the multiple nature of undernutrition and malnutrition causes, including food insecurity, health, sanitation, social safety nets and inequalities, and the needed nutrition—specific interventions. This balance is to be better assessed in the programming exercise with partner countries and other donors. This may also include a further look into our development instruments in 2017.  We have taken due note of Parliament’s request to increase the Commission’s funding for nutrition-specific actions. In this context, the Commission has put forward the following approach: we should maximise the synergies and complementarities of our development and humanitarian responses to nutrition and food security needs, having in mind that humanitarian responses are, in principle, nutrition-specific.  We will promote programming coordination with other donors, who can focus on nutrition-specific interventions, thus complementing the Commission’s focus on nutrition-sensitive issues. We shall also advocate at global level, especially through the Scaling Up Nutrition (SUN) movement, to increase investment in nutrition, including nutrition-specific investments by both donors and developing countries.  The first results of this three-pronged approach are encouraging, notably in Rwanda, Ethiopia, Niger, Mali, Bangladesh, Laos and Guatemala. We support partner countries in developing and implementing their own true multi—sectoral nutrition action plans, which combine nutrition-specific and nutrition-sensitive interventions. This also allows donors to align their support to national priorities and coordinate the division of nutrition efforts.  The Commission has gained a strong record and evidence in supporting nutrition, mainly through the agriculture, education, water or health sectors. However, the Commission is exploring other areas, such as social safety nets, which have proved to be successful in improving nutrition – particularly in Mali. In this context, the Commission and the Club du Sahel are organising a major event on social protection for nutrition in Abuja in December. The objective will be to further increase investments and to reduce undernutrition faster, while putting women, children, and small farmers at the centre of nutrition actions.  At the global level, the Commission will continue advocating further investment in nutrition, notably through the Scaling Up Nutrition movement. We should also explore with the SUN Movement the opportunity to organise a pledging event for nutrition in the coming years.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. According to united nations data, as colleague Guerrero has already mentioned, currently 795 million people (i.e. 1 in 10 people) are malnourished. This figure is projected to rise to 2 billion by 2050. The agricultural sector is not only a food supplier, but is also considered the largest employer in the world (it provides livelihoods for more than 40% of the world's population). Combating poverty and eradicating hunger, as well as supporting this sector of the economy, should be the overarching objective of the European Union, the second point of the SDGs. Hunger has particularly negative consequences for children, and the effects are felt not only on an individual scale, but also on societies as a whole, resulting in a inhibition of personal development and further negative social consequences. Estimates for 2016 indicate that in Ethiopia alone, the number of people who will be affected by hunger will increase from 10 million to 18 million, and already it is about 6 million children.  Action to address these problems also means helping to tackle other threats, from social to migration. I hope that, in the light of the foregoing, you will answer the questions of the Committee on Development and show the way forward to improve this situation.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: On behalf of the Group of S-D. - Mr President, the UN Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food, Olivier De Schutter, stressed the essential role of agriculture in terms of development.  It is clear that in our policies we must be consistent on this issue and try to ensure that agriculture is a source of food self-sufficiency around the world. Today, through our policies, we are turning our backs on this food self-sufficiency. In the economic partnership agreements we sign with Africa, ultimately, we make African countries dependent on European business, which thwarts their normal agricultural development. Similarly, at European level, our common agricultural policy is perhaps the only one of the world's major agricultural producers that decouples aid. For example, CAP aid - which accounts for 40% of the EU budget - is completely decoupled from the economic reality of agriculture.  It is therefore clear that aid must be cross-referenced with economic reality. We must ensure consistency in our various international agreements and ensure that agriculture develops around the world, especially in areas where people are hungry. I would like to remind you that 70% of the world's malnourished people are rural farmers.

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, the eradication of hunger and malnutrition is a great commitment of the European Union. Our intention must be to achieve sustainable development within Objective II, but also the related objectives, which aim to eradicate both hunger and malnutrition, by 2030. However, the current situation shows that our policies so far are ineffective and wrong and I disagree with the encouraging results and figures mentioned.  The new objectives can be achieved mainly by increasing the productivity of small crops and properties and by creating sustainable farming and food production systems capable of fuelling a total population expected to reach 8.5 billion people. It is therefore particularly important to carry out coordinated actions between the global community and national and local authorities, non-governmental organisations and the private sector, as well as between donors to tackle famines and all forms of malnutrition, through increased production and a more efficient process of developing the productive food chain.  On this basis, the European Union should also take into account the need for greater coherence and coordination between all the institutions and bodies of the European Union and the Member States. Member States should step up, in line with their commitments, their efforts for global food security and give priority to sustainable agriculture and local food production, as well as to supporting small farmers and women farmers as food producers. At the same time, the international community and the European Union must work with all countries to support the development and implementation of an integrated framework with concrete, achievable and strong national and supranational food measures, on the basis of sustainable development objectives, in order to reduce underdevelopment and malnutrition.  As far as production is concerned, careful and scientific selection of crops should be made, by educating farmers and adapting to local climatic and soil conditions, but also to the needs of local populations. Finally, humanitarian aid must be targeted, not exploited by corrupt actors, waste must be avoided and supplemented by Commission strategies linking humanitarian and development aid. At the same time, the Commission should increase investment in specific nutrition-related interventions, especially given the current huge funding gap. Finally, I would like to remind you, Commissioner, that huge European populations are currently starving.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. "Mr. President, let's look at the world we live in. On the one hand, we are discussing in this Parliament how to protect the EU's top agricultural products. And I'm participating in that discussion, and I support that. But on the other hand, we have acute hunger.  In Parliament, we often talk about the fact that food in European restaurants, supermarkets, shops is thrown away a lot, and on the other hand, ladies and gentlemen, we have an acute hunger, which is present mainly and primarily in Africa, but not only on this continent. We have a situation where today hundreds of millions of people live on the brink of famine, on the verge of existence. Unfortunately, a huge number of them, millions, are children.  What is a paradox in this whole story is that often the people who live by the land, by the land, on the ground, are the ones who are hungry. I'm talking about Africa again. Japan set a good example and in some African countries set out to educate and learn how to grow rice. I know that our Commission is also working on educating the population in Africa, how to produce their own food, because I have always been convinced that whoever is hungry should be helped, but primarily by give him a hook so that he can catch fish, not give him fish.  And in this context, I am convinced that our politics must also go in this direction. Help with fish, therefore concrete food aid, but primarily help in education and the way food is produced in developing countries.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, 800 million people in the world are starving. More than three million children die each year from malnutrition. Hunger in the world is not a problem of supply, but of poverty, of the absence of democracy and unequal access to land and water, especially for women. But our trade and development policies only delve deeper into this path, and then I want to focus on one concrete aspect.  Civil society and experts have echoed the serious threat posed by the planned mergers between large food multinationals, which would eventually control most of the world's agricultural supplies. It would involve further price increases, the privatization of research and therefore higher rates of poverty and hunger. Corporate control of food is already expelling small producers, which produce, in the case of Africa, up to 80% of the food consumed.  From the European institutions we must regulate a right as basic as food, so that it is not left to three multinational giants that pursue only business and speculation, and not end hunger. Let us not trust them, ladies and gentlemen.

name: Maria HEUBUCH
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has We all know it and have heard it several times now that, despite all our efforts, more than 800 million people are still malnourished and starving. Other people have proper malnutrition, which means that minerals such as iron, iodine and zinc are not sufficiently present in their diets, which really leads to major health problems – especially in children. And more children die from the effects of hunger than from AIDS, malaria and tuberculosis combined.  Despite these catastrophic situations, there is too little intervention in development policy, and only a fraction of the financial needs are met. I really can only welcome the Commission's commitment to invest EUR 3.5 billion in food here. But we also know that this is not enough to achieve Sustainability Goal 2, which will end hunger by 2030. That is why Parliament is calling for another billion. But it's not just the money that counts, it doesn't just matter how much money comes in, it also counts how it's spent – the key things are the measures we take with that money. Because it is not only enough to provide enough calories, but we need a diverse, healthy diet, and that means in the end: we have to produce the food where it is needed. Sixty per cent of the world's farmers and fishermen are starving. And another 20 percent of the hungry are farm workers. Therefore, the grotesque thing about this situation – something that really moves me very much – is that the people who actually produce food themselves are not adequately fed. They need access to water, land, tools, adapted seeds. And that must take precedence, priority over industrial interests in these regions. I would like to point out once again that the people who live in these regions where food is produced must go to bed again tonight, hungry – and that is what we see as a scandal.

name: Raymond FINCH
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the Commission may well promote itself as a champion in the field of enhancing nutrition and food security. However, it is clear that tens of millions of taxpayers’ money will again be misused and channelled to the wrong projects with no tracking or real control whatsoever. Besides that, there is the danger that the EU is influencing the political agenda in the governments concerned, causing more instability.  However, there is another point that I would like to make. On the one hand, the EU promotes itself as a champion of development, providing poor countries with aid and assistance to deal with food security and food shortages. But, on the other hand, the EU is undermining food security in many parts of the world. Taxpayers in the EU are forced to bear the cost of EU fisheries agreements, which are essentially a tool to allow a few big fishing companies to plunder the waters of poor African coastal nations. People of poor coastal communities rely on fish as an affordable source of protein. Fish is their main source of food and they need it to survive, but we are stealing it from them. The plundering of these fish stocks has led to serious protein deficiencies within these communities. It is threatening food security and causing malnutrition. We can only hope that when we leave the EU, which we will do shortly, we can then promote true food security and sustainability.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). Mr President, we are faced with an important problem which is unfortunately expected to worsen in the coming years. A large proportion of the world's population is malnourished at the same time that large quantities of food, especially in Western societies, end up in the garbage every year. Social injustices existed, exist and will continue to exist in the future. However, from the position we are in, we must make the greatest possible efforts to alleviate them both within the Union and internationally.  The global food market - with a large share of the responsibility of the European Union, the governments of the Member States, but above all of the shape of the world economy - is not aimed at meeting food needs worldwide, but at achieving the maximum possible profit. But people are not numbers and balance sheets. The lack of food creates other, incalculable problems that do not concern multinational companies at all.  Our proposal is to introduce a certain rate of self-sufficiency for the Union. A certain proportion of food must necessarily be produced within the Union, which will benefit European producers while at the same time directing production from third countries, for the benefit of their peoples.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by In today's Europe, especially in the western part of Europe, the anti-globalism movement is developing and strengthening. I would like to talk about this in this regard, because it is extremely important. Globalism today is the globalism of democracy. Globalism today is the globalism of the rule of law, the globalism of equality. Modern globalism in the 21st century is the globalism of education. This is civil society globalism. After all, nowadays globalism is the dissemination of prosperity in the world. All those who are against globalisation in Europe, so de facto – I understand that without awareness – are in favour of promoting poverty, of maintaining poverty. A world in which countries would only close within their borders, where communities would act only within their agreements, and not worry about other states, other nations, that would be a world dominated by poverty. This process of globalisation, which we are currently seeing and developing positively, serves the ideals that we are talking about here today. And I hope that those who have an impact on public life in Europe and around the world understand that. Through globalisation, we will work to reduce poverty in the world.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, I strongly support this report, which underlines the importance of the development of social safety nets. I would like to underline the importance of achieving sustainable development goal 2, which aims to end hunger and malnutrition by 2030, notably by increasing the productivity of smallholders’ farms, and achieving sustainable and climate resilient agriculture and food systems.  Currently 159 million children are stunted and 50 million are affected by wasting. Malnutrition has a tremendous impact on their development and health and fuels the cycle of poverty. The level of investment remains inadequate. The Commission Nutrition Action Plan pledged to reduce stunting by 7 million children by 2025 and should honour its commitments, ensuring it addresses all forms of under-nutrition while also filling the huge current funding gap for nutrition—specific interventions.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Speaking in this debate, I would like to remind you that, according to fao data from just a few years ago, global food production should increase by at least 75% by 2030, which means that agriculture and food production should be under the special protection of individual countries and their associations, such as the European Union, which, after all, has been funding the common agricultural policy for almost 50 years. The Polish delegation in the EKR Group, on whose behalf I am speaking, wants, of course, to support most of the provisions of the forthcoming European Parliament resolution on nutrition and food security, including in particular the promotion of small agricultural producers, the fight against land-taking in developing countries or opposition to the so-called privatisation of seeds, which directly threatens the food sovereignty of individual countries. On this occasion, however, I would like to remind you that the reforms of the common agricultural policy implemented by the European Union itself are very often aimed at reducing agricultural production in Europe. Huge sums of billions of euros are financed by programmes to reduce production, such as sugar and, more recently, milk, which is, after all, contrary to food security both in Europe and globally.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Mr President, the EU has committed to reducing the number of chronically undernourished children by at least seven million by 2025 with a nutrition action plan. Indeed, progress in hunger reduction has been substantial in spite of the difficult global environment.  The proportion of undernourished people in the developing world has dropped from 18 % in the 1990s to 10 % in 2014. However, the path towards the total eradication of hunger will be a long one. If we continue at this tempo, many children, women and those living in poverty will pay the price. That is why more consecrated action is required from us. We need to step up and tackle rising unemployment by creating the conditions for growth. Volatile commodity prices, economic recessions and, primarily, political instability and wars. Nutrition is an investment for our collective future. Here is where the EU has a crucial role, so let’s play it!

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: – In two weeks' time it will be World Food Day, but by 8 August we had already used more of the earth than it can offer us. Mr President, in my youth there was no Earth Overshoot Day, but today a generation is growing up that takes what it wants, even if it is at the expense of others.  Today, one billion people are overweight and almost one billion people go to bed hungry. Not because there is too little food, but because of our own consumption patterns and our own agricultural policy. We can feed anyone if we stop wasting food. We can feed everyone if Brussels no longer intensifies and encourages overproduction. We can feed anyone if we give kids apples instead of school milk.  Mr President, tomorrow is World Animal Day and the Party for Animals is asking you to reflect on the 7 billion animals in our livestock industry, because we can fight hunger and save these animals a long agony by stopping wasting food on animal feed. I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Mr President, ending hunger by 2030 is not about increasing production of commodities for global markets; rather we need to put nutrition, health and food security at the core of agricultural policy. We need a fundamental shift towards agro-ecology so that countries can feed themselves with a diversity of crops while addressing climate and poverty challenges. Support to family farmers and smallholders is key.  The EuroLat Assembly, of which I am a member, is debating a resolution on food security, recommending measures such as food reserves which governments can use to mitigate short term price fluctuations. In the EU, the Commission has a role in reducing volatility by ensuring that robust position limits are put in place to curb food speculation, as citizens rightly expect from the MiFID 2 Agreement.  The right to food also depends on access to land, yet inconsistencies in EU sectoral policies are inhibiting this. Current policies towards biofuels and many liberalising trade and investment agreements are jeopardising food security, contributing directly or indirectly to land grabbing.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, our stated and stated objective is to put an end to hunger and malnutrition in the world by 2030. Tomorrow, the Secretary-General of the United Nations, Ban Ki-moon, will probably remind us of this with his presence here in Strasbourg. Unfortunately, however, the stated objective really seems out of reach. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, would you agree with me that we are lagging far behind this objective today? Do you not think that, by continuing with this step, we will never be able to achieve it? It is absurd that even today we should see the timely and daily exploitation of people and land by private interests for their own exclusive benefit, without any regard for the lives of others. Our efforts on food and global food security issues must be stepped up. We must make serious efforts to relaunch and support small agricultural producers and local food production, to develop effective and resilient agricultural policies, to ensure access to land and to stop land grabbing once and for all.  If we want to try to achieve this, the way is to guarantee food sovereignty to those who should be its main beneficiaries, namely the local populations. For all this, with these objectives firmly in mind, today we call on the Commission and the european Union as a whole to look again at this issue and to question the effectiveness of its actions, in order to consider a different intervention, based on transparency and the protection of local populations.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr We live in a time of paradoxes. It's been pointed out here tonight, but it's sick how it looks. On the one hand, we have this Parliament that can talk about how to reduce food waste. On the other hand, we have nearly 800 million people who suffer from getting too little food.  We live in a time when, at lightning speed, we can find out that people are at risk of starvation – I am thinking of El Niño this spring. At the same time, it takes months for the outside world to come together to support and help the vulnerable. I still see in front of me the hungry children and the tired looks of the children who can not be bothered to play anymore.  I now support the calls for the Commission to take a more effective lead in food safety security – where coordination and long-term ism are a key – and also want the Commission to respond to what is being made for the El Niño-affected areas.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: – Mr President, the world's population is projected to grow to 9.5 billion by 2050. Thus, securing food for all the people of the world must be the number one priority.  I believe that it is essential that the quality of food is emphasised more than just empty calories. At present, a lot of food is produced in quantitative terms, but calories from current main cereals such as maize, wheat and rice, for example, do not contain enough essential trace elements. The poorest citizens in the world often depend on the main cereals produced in that country. It is therefore important that, in future, development is steered towards this main cereal being more often a nutrient-rich oat, barley, rye, mill mille and sorghum.  At present, up to two billion people suffer from iron deficiency and one fifth of the world's population lives in zinc deprivation. Estimates have been made that around 170 million children suffer from nutrient deficiency and the resulting slowdown in growth, so the importance of the nutritional content of crops cannot be overemphasised.  Innovations in vegetarian food should therefore be promoted even more. Pulled oats and fava bean preparation developed in Finland are examples of sustainable solutions for the future.

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Hunger in the poorest countries is also largely caused by our trade policy. We are pushing african states into trade agreements that allow us to fish their coasts empty. We demand unrestricted access to their markets, where we sell our highly subsidized agricultural products. In many areas, local farmers, who are not subsidised, simply can no longer keep up with our prices. We urge them to work for export, to grow cocoa, coffee, fruit, southern fruits, flowers. The problem is that trade to Europe, to the US, usually makes a single, sometimes two, trading companies that are depressing prices, which give farmers so little that they cannot live on it and cannot die. We produce hunger. Our trade policy, the EU's trade policy, is worse than what happened in colonial policy 100 years ago.

name: Paolo DE CASTRO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the instability of the markets for agricultural raw materials, population growth and changing diets globally, environmental constraints on food production and the consequences of climate change are all components of a scenario of new scarcity. In this scenario, agriculture is called upon to play a leading role in the increasingly pressing global challenge of access to food, not only from a productive perspective, but also for its ability to generate employment and stability in the most marginalised areas of the planet. A role recognised by the United Nations itself, which place the issue of food security at the heart of the Sustainable Development Goals of the 2030 Agenda. Commissioner, this issue is global and must be addressed as such. We therefore need a genuine Global Food Policy and Europe must take on a leading role that it has unfortunately only announced so far, a leading role in the definition of inclusive and innovative development measures that guarantee social and territorial cohesion, involving groups hitherto considered to be the most vulnerable in decision-making and governance processes.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, among the Union's objectives and commitments on food security on the planet we find the eradication of hunger and poor nutrition by 2030, by increasing the productivity of small farms and achieving sustainable food systems in climate change. This includes reducing the number of stunted people by 7 million worldwide by 2025, with the European Union committed to allocate EUR 3.5 billion in 2014-2020 for this purpose. In 2014, of course, only 0.57% of total official development aid was allocated to interventions aimed at eradicating global malnutrition. Given that 159 million children are poor and 50 million suffer from atrophy, it is clear that immediate action should be taken by the Union in favour of food security, and that all official development aid should be used.  In addition, food security on the planet is related to the use of safe food, which means that mutants should be hit and organic farming and livestock farming strengthened. But how can this be done, Commissioner, when in Greece over the last five years organic livestock farmers have not gotten the aid they are entitled to from the European Union? The same applies, Commissioner, to farmers who support the conservation of endangered breeds of farm animals. They are also still waiting for subsidies. So what is going to happen, Commissioner? What will you do to make Greek farmers pay their subsidies?

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: – Mr President, as several Members have said here, including, most recently, colleague De Castro, we need a global food policy. And if the globe, the Earth as a whole, is understood to be part of Europe, then I must say that there is much to be done here, on the European continent. It is probably because of the various stumbles that many people have said that we have little experience on home soil, i.e. within the European Union, and there are very serious problems here too. Mr President, I would like to say that in the eastern part of Europe, including in my own country, Hungary, 2% of the population is effective malnourished and starving. The vast majority of these, of course, are children, on top of everything. If we were to deal with the food of these, we might be able to make it much easier for us to prevail on the international stage. But this is not only the case, but also that, as long as there is no uniform tax policy on food in the European Union, it will be that in Hungary there will be 27% VAT on food and zero in others.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today some 800 million people, most of them in rural areas, are still suffering from hunger and more than 2 billion are malnourished. With the new Sustainable Development Goals, we have committed ourselves not only to ending chronic hunger, but also to working for greater food security and combating malnutrition because, once the need for food is met, it is to the quality and variety of the diet that we must look at.  To do that, the FAO tells us that we would need $267 billion a year for investment. This would only be 0.3 % of the world's GDP in order to diversify cultures, invest seriously in rural populations, particularly small agricultural producers, and promote sustainable agriculture. If we do not want the new SDGs to remain on paper, we need more resources – we are asking for this – and we also need a European framework for implementing SDGs.  Coordination between the Commission and the Member States on this is essential, because they are universal objectives, and I ask the Commissioner when we will finally have this European framework on the implementation of the new Development Goals.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, I would like to focus specifically on women and girls, who suffer more nutritional deficiencies than men for reasons such as women’s reproductive biology, low social status, poverty and lack of education. Although malnutrition’s effects on this group have been recognised for decades, there has been little measurable progress in addressing the specific nutritional problems of women and adolescent girls. Addressing women’s malnutrition has a range of positive effects because healthy women can fulfil their multiple roles more effectively, thereby helping to advance their country’s socio-economic development. Secondly, more consideration should be given to the power of civil society and people—to—people initiatives in making real differences in their communities, such as the World Vision Gicumbi Child Nutrition Centre that I recently visited in Rwanda.  Finally, I want to emphasise the role that education and intercultural dialogue plays as a key tool in development, emphasising and transforming mindsets and addressing key causes of under—nutrition. Fighting against malnutrition requires access to education.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – We often talk about human rights in this Chamber, and certainly the right to food, to quality, healthy food is a basic human right. I therefore very much support all the programmes implemented by the European Union, both in the form of humanitarian aid and in the form of development aid. I think that the time has come for us to really focus on development aid for the European Union in that, in the countries where the greatest food shortages, that is, the most important in Africa, are helping to develop a little agriculture, agriculture, which is in some way the basis for people getting food for the first time, secondly, to develop jobs. Education, exchange of experience, and here I think Europe can do a lot. Because if we are successful on this problem, on the problem of food security, we will also partly solve the major problem of migration, which we will continue to face in the global format.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT OBJECTIVE of the UN Agenda aims to end hunger in the world by 2030 through increased productivity of small farmers and the incentive of sustainable agriculture. However, we must take note of the fact that simply ensuring greater production and greater availability of food is not enough to solve the problem. The latest available data tells us that more than 159 million children worldwide suffer from growth lag. In the light of this, the implementation of European policies developed by the Commission's action plan on nutrition must be implemented. Food and nutrition security needs constant strategic attention, as well as investment support, especially in rural areas. Policy-making and planning must take into account the links between nutrition, health and job creation, growth and sustainable production. The European Union must work strategically to determine the conditions for combating food waste and for promoting the development of sustainable and quality agriculture, with particular reference to the support of small and very small farms.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, the persistence of hunger, the persistence of millions of cases of chronic malnutrition in the world, at a time when scientific and technological development is reaching levels that could easily eradicate this phenomenon, is one of the most living accusatory libels that weighs on the largely dominant capitalist system on a global scale.  The reasons for hunger are political, first and foremost. It is not by chance that we are witnessing a decline in the phenomenon even in countries normally included in the batch of so-called 'developed' countries. Let us look, for example, at the devastating effects of the European Union and IMF programmes. Free trade that ruins small agriculture, family farming and food sovereignty of entire nations, land usurpation, transnational monopoly of agribusiness over seeds and other production factors, dismantling of public infrastructure and services, and attacking the social functions of states are among the unavoidable causes of hunger, and a genuine effort to combat hunger must , must take into account the need to tackle their causes.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, this is a very important topic, and again I think it shows the genuine commitment of the European Union to helping all peoples in the world. It is a commitment that is genuine and sincere and to which we give a lot of support and for which we get very little credit, not to mention publicity. Nevertheless, it is work that needs to be done, because when millions and millions of people around the world – especially children – are dying of malnutrition on the one hand, and then in our own first-world many of them are suffering from obesity, there is a reconciliation there that needs to be done, which will not be easy. One area that I would like to see much more emphasis placed on is the whole area of research and development – especially research. With climate change, some places are getting warmer and drier while other places are getting wetter and colder. Crops need to adjust, and I think we need to do a lot more research in that regard.

name: Seán KELLY
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, if we want to achieve the sustainable development goals we must pursue our efforts to eradicate undernutrition. The Commission spent almost EUR 500 million per year on nutrition interventions, representing 3.1% of its development aid in 2014.  The European Union is also addressing undernutrition through its humanitarian assistance. We had EUR 700 million spent between 2011 and 2015. But we all must do more.  We will continue keeping our development policy focus on nutrition and food security issues, as well as advocating further investment in nutrition by other donors and partner countries. We will explore with a strong movement the possible Pledging Conference on Nutrition. We will continue also to explore other interventions, such as the social safety nets, as well as reflecting on the balance between nutrition-sensitive and nutrition-specific interventions. We will continue to coordinate with donors who focus on nutrition-specific interventions, as well as maximising the synergies and complementarities of our development and humanitarian responses.  This development humanitarian collaboration has been further confirmed by the Commission’s response to the food crisis generated by El Niño climate change phenomenon. The Commission allocated an additional EUR 543 million this year, almost equally shared between humanitarian and development interventions. This is coherent with the resilience approach, which aims at meeting the more immediate needs of populations in food crisis while addressing the root causes of partner countries’ fragility and vulnerability.  I am confident that the proposed resolution on nutrition of the European Parliament, the Nutrition Action Plan of the Commission and the Council conclusions on nutrition can help the European Union improve nutrition and make undernutrition history, as foreseen in sustainable development goals agenda by 2030.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I have received one motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule 128(5) of the Rules of Procedure. I close the debate. The vote will take place on Wednesday 5 October 2016. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. – Hunger and malnutrition are the epicentre of one of the biggest issues we have to fight today. One in six children are underweight for their age and even though since 1990 the amount of people being effected by malnutrition has halved, there are still millions of people not receiving enough food and water. The percentage of development assistance dedicated to malnutrition should be increased and coupled with long-term goals for prevention of hunger. More specifically, we should pay more attention to small farmers, who at this moment produce around 70% of the world’s food. Increasing their potential yield and diversifying the seeds being grown gives the surrounding area not only short-term assistance but also the tools to combat malnutrition in the long run.
