In addition, toddlers and new-born babies are severely affected by malnutrition; this is impacted by the fact that breastfeeding is still not fully recognised as an acceptable and culturally—decent practice in many places. The EP report tackles this issue by calling on the EU for a worldwide campaign highlighting the importance of breastfeeding and its necessity for a growing baby.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Food security, in addition to energy security and defence security, is the most important global challenge in the world today. This is mainly due to the ever-growing population, expected to grow to 8.5 billion by 2030 and, moreover, according to forecasts by the FAO (World Food and Agriculture Organisation) by 2050, food demand will increase by 70%. Feeding the population will become the world's main problem, and for this reason we are seeing an increase in land appropriation in developing countries and more. I call on the Commission to take concrete measures to combat the expropriation of agricultural land and to draw up an action plan to combat land purchases and to ensure the effective implementation of the FAO guidelines on property.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. – We have been talking about malnutrition and hunger for decades, but despite the development aid allocated to the sub-Saharan states, malnutrition and hunger still exist. Unfortunately, even though the Action Plan of the Nutrition Commission has committed to reduce the number of cases of growth retardation among children by 7 million by 2025, a total commitment of 3.5 billion only 400 million is allocated to nutrition-specific measures. In 2012, the World Health Assembly approved a set of six global nutrition targets for 2025, including the target of reducing the number of growth retardation cases among children under five years of age by 40%. However, investment in nutrition remains insufficient. The European Commission should increase nutrition aid and support the development of the agricultural sector in countries facing famine.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission by Linda McAvan, on behalf of the Committee on Development, Giovanni La Via, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, Bernd Lange, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, Czesław Adam Siekierski, on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, and Jerzy Buzek, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, on combating illegal logging, deforestation and forest degradation - EU action programme (O-000112/2016 - B8-0720/2016) (2016/2824(RSP)).

name: Paavo VÄYRYNEN
text: author. – Mr President, in 2003 the European Union took action against illegal logging and trade in illegally—logged tree timber by adopting the FLEGT Action Plan, the central element of which is the system of voluntary partnership agreements signed between the EU and timber—producing countries in Africa, Asia and Latin America.  In 2015, the European Court of Auditors issued a special report identifying gaps in FLEGT implementation and enforcement. The Court found that EU support to timber—producing countries was not sufficiently effective and targeted and called for an appropriate work plan with clear objectives, milestones and a dedicated budget. The Court also found that monitoring and reporting on progress had been inadequate, in particular due to the lack of an accountability framework.  The Commission has recently issued an evaluation of the FLEGT Action Plan, 12 years after its entry into force. Given this context, five committees asked the Commission to answer the following questions. First, how will the Commission concretely respond to the European Court of Auditors recommendations in its Special Report No 13/2015? Will additional resources be mobilised to respond to implementation challenges and will specific monitoring and evaluation mechanisms be developed to strengthen implementation of the EU Action Plan on Forest Law Enforcement, Governance and Trade? What is the Commission strategy to revive the political momentum for FLEGT in voluntary partnership agreement countries and to accelerate the governance reforms that are necessary for the issuance of FLEGT licences? Thirdly, how is the Commission ensuring coherence and synergies between climate mitigation policies and FLEGT, especially on governance aspects?

name: David MARTIN
text: author. – Mr President, I am speaking on behalf of Bernd Lange, who cannot be here this evening. Illegal logging and trade in illegal timber has a devastating impact on the world’s forests, threatening the survival of various wildlife species and contributing to climate change. Regrettably, we have not managed to reverse global deforestation, even though illegal timber imports to the EU have declined. This signals the urgent need to step up our efforts. The Committee on International Trade is a lead committee for FLEGT, the voluntary partnership agreements that are signed under the FLEGT Regulation between the EU and timber-producing countries, and that should address the supply side of the problem.  I note with satisfaction that Indonesia will be the first country to start issuing FLEGT licenses this autumn, and the whole process has contributed to strengthened forest governance through an inclusive multi-stakeholder approach. Today, over 90% of Indonesia’s timber exports are from independently—audited factories and forests, compared to just 20% in 2002. It is an important milestone, especially as one third by value of the EU’s tropical timber imports come from Indonesia. I would like to hear from the Commission how they are going to step up and accelerate the process in other Voluntary Partnership Agreement countries (VPAs). Could the Commission indicate which VPA countries, in addition to Indonesia, are closest to signing FLEGT licenses, and – as we have just heard, this is especially relevant in light of the Court of Auditors recommendation – notably that resources should be allocated to where they are likely to have the greatest impact in tackling illegal logging and related trade? In cases where implementation of the VPA requirements appears less feasible, would the Commission agree to propose measures supporting forest governance without necessarily signing a VPA?

name: David MARTIN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I have to start by saying and reconfirming that the EU is strongly committed to the fight against illegal logging and the associated trade. The FLEGT Action Plan has built an effective global coalition against it, tackling both the supply and demand sides through trade measures, through development cooperation and through broad stakeholder engagement. Our action plan tackles some of the real drivers of deforestation and forest degradation. But deforestation continues and its consequences are potentially catastrophic at many levels – for the local communities that depend on forests, for the ecosystems that they support and at the global level as we deplete one of the most effective carbon sinks that we have. We must continue this fight both through our own actions and in the new global dynamic of the 2030 Agenda and the Paris Agreement. The honourable Members are right to raise their concerns, and I welcome the interest of the Parliament in the follow-up to the European Court of Auditors report. FLEGT has been the subject of two reviews in the past two years. EU support to timber production countries under FLEGT was reviewed by the European Court of Auditors, while the overall performance of the action plan was also independently evaluated.  A basic finding is that FLEGT remains highly relevant and that the work carried out so far under the action plan is delivering significant results. Forest governance has improved, particularly in targeted countries, while demand for illegal timber in the EU has been reduced. The design of FLEGT has also been found to be future proof.  That being said, things have changed since the inception of the action plan. Imports of tropical timber in the EU have fallen, whilst China has become the world’s largest market and global political attention has shifted to other drivers of deforestation such as the competition for land and to other drivers of climate change. The evaluation stressed that such changes may have an impact on the relevance of the action plan if not sufficiently addressed. That is why the Commission has been considering opportunities to scale up efforts to combat deforestation through FLEGT but also through other instruments such as REDD+ and the EU timber regulation.  We have now commissioned a study to consider the feasibility of a comprehensive EU action plan on deforestation. The review of the Court and of the independent evaluation have highlighted important implementation challenges and areas for improvement in the way the FLEGT Action Plan has been managed, particularly in relation to the support to the countries concerned, and have recommended adjustments.  We are working to address these findings to a multiannual work plan with clear objectives, targets, timeframes and budget. This will redefine priorities geographically and thematically and will ensure more effective monitoring of progress, achievements and impact. FLEGT is our flagship priority under the Global Public Goods and Challenges Programme of the European Development Cooperation Instrument, but we should remember that the action plan is a joint initiative. It must draw on the combined strengths and capacities of the EU and of its Member States. According to the evaluation, stronger commitment and more active support by more Member States is needed.  Finally, the honourable Members also asked about voluntary partnership agreements (VPAs). As mentioned by Paavo Väyrynen, VPAs are a central FLEGT element, and the Commission has invested intensely in their negotiation and implementation through political dialogue, through stakeholder engagement and through capacity building.  Our colleague David Martin also mentioned Indonesia and yes, soon we will be launching Indonesia’s FLEGT licensing, and hopefully Ghana will follow soon after, hopefully next year. These efforts are yielding good results in those countries where there is willingness to implement the necessary reforms. The difficulty of putting in place these reforms should not be underestimated. There are often strong vested interests, benefiting from the status quo.  We will, of course, continue to make all possible efforts to maintain political momentum in VPAs and address the challenges with our partner countries.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the Commission for your – Thank you very much first of all to your colleagues for asking this very important question and, of course, also to you, Commissioner Vella, for the answers you gave us at the beginning of this point. The European Union is aware of the importance of the forest ecosystem, which is why, since the 1990s, it has been dealing with the problem of illegal shrinkage, trade in this timber and, as you said, even through these, now 25 years, things have been changing significantly. I do not know, China is now emerging as the biggest buyer, and in the meantime, the European Union has also committed and, as the European Court of Justice has also reviewed, as much as €300 million in resources, in order to improve this forest management worldwide and to improve forest management, as well as on common recommendations. In addition to the great biodiversity, which is one of the key problems in the face of environmental damage, there is certainly a major problem in this area, the area of corruption and, in fact, the failure of the countries where we come from. Therefore, in some ways, there is also a minor disappointment that we have only a few signed, that is, an agreement with Indonesia and some agreements with African countries. I wish you every success in this part because, as I have already said, I very much support that this issue be resolved. These problems, we want or don't want, they come to our homes sooner or later. Let me just say my own experience from Slovenia from a good two years ago, when in the winter of 2004 we suffered great damage after a great gutter, that is, climate change, causing various phenomena, great damage, when almost half of the Slovenian forest was forsageed into ice and as a result, two years after that, we feel after a very hot year with the underheabs that are destroying the now pine forest. So that the problem we are talking about, at first glance, seems to be very far from us, and the consequences are also felt very quickly on our own soil. I therefore support these efforts, in this direction, as you mentioned, here on this point.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Commissioner Vella for his commitments and answers. There are countries where the illegal logging rate reaches 90 %, implying forms of corruption throughout the slaughter, transport and sales chain. The objectives set out in the Action Plan are still hampered by a multitude of factors, including resistance to change in the forestry sector, the delay in implementing the European regulation, the importance of other markets such as China and India, and the boom in agricultural raw materials whose production occupies forest land. Extensive farming plays a key role in the process of deforestation, when we consider that since 2000 about half of the tropical forest has been converted into agricultural land or for monoculture plantations, often against the will of indigenous peoples, as is the case with palm oil in Indonesia, Liberia and Ecuador. It is estimated that today 80 % of global deforestation is caused by agriculture and, with the import of products such as palm oil, beef, leather, soya, rubber, cocoa and timber, the European Union is also a major player in this problem. In addition, the environmental damage caused by deforestation cannot be underestimated. In addition to the very serious loss of biodiversity, deforestation is one of the main causes of hydrogeological failure and causes floods and landslides. The EU must therefore demonstrate and continue to demonstrate a strong political commitment to the effective implementation of voluntary partnership agreements, to strengthen their impact, to ensure the effective implementation of the Timber Regulation and to take further measures to support the protection and recovery of forest ecosystems.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: on behalf of the ECR Club. – Dear President, the issue of illegal logging, deforestation and forest degradation is of particular importance for my homeland Croatia because almost half of its territory is covered with forests. In recent years, the activities of the so-called "forest mafia", which steal thousands of cubic meters of wood mass annually, whether firewood or expensive oak and beech logs, which are illegally supplied by the wood-processing industry, have become more pronounced. The problem is particularly pronounced in private forests whose owners do not live on their property and where property-legal relations are not settled, but also does not bypass state forests. Thieves are well organized and networked, state foresters cannot effectively patrol and prevent thefts in so much space, and police find it difficult to trace thieves. If we really want to protect forests, the state must manage those it owns more efficiently, and we should encourage private forest owners to set up private forestry associations and introduce a system of joint control that would involve constant exchange of information with state forestry and police. For countries like Croatia, wood is in every sense a strategic resource and we must not allow anyone to illegally claim it and its robberies threaten the future of our forests, their ecosystem and the future of our children.

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the I particularly welcome the debate here in plenary on the FLEGT action plan. A globally sustainable logging and trade of wood is the basis for a functioning timber industry. Personally, it is particularly important to me to be careful with our resource and to protect our markets. Illegal logging has been a concern for us for a long time. Here are a few facts: about 20 to 40% of global timber production is illegally cut. The economic damage is about 15 billion dollars due to lost revenue in the area of the state, the municipalities, the industry, but also the private forest owners. Worldwide, this will reduce the price of wood by about 10%. About 16% of timber imports into the European Union come from illegal logging, and the World Bank even talks about organised crime, which must be combated with tougher laws. So we cannot continue to watch here. Today we are evaluating the FLEGT action plan. It was intended to address and resolve the problems. At the heart of the action plan are bilateral agreements between Europe and the timber exporting countries. Despite all efforts to establish responsible rule of law here, rainforests continue to be cleared and biodiversity destroyed. Our precautionary measures have so far had little success. We need action against the backers of trade. Let us therefore pick up on the most important points from the Court of Auditors. I call on you here to also adopt a clear strategy, to explain coherent work plans, priorities, timetables and milestones, and to finally create a set of rules out of this toothless tiger that will be implemented equally in all countries throughout Europe.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, I believe that the European Union could do much more to discourage illegal logging in the world. It could start, for example, by discouraging the monoculture of eucalyptus or other fast-growing species and promoting instead the production of quality woods. This would go a long way in maintaining biodiversity, also maintaining the environment.  It seems to me that another very important aspect that the European Union could take into account in discouraging illegal logging would be not only voluntary measures, but to end illegal trade by controlling imports and also importers.  Promoting a forestry policy in Europe that encourages forest management, prevents deforestation of agricultural land and enhances the production of quality timber would be a great contribution to this project.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, it is of the utmost importance that the Commission really comes up with a comprehensive EU action plan on deforestation and forest degradation. We have lots of reasons and obligations as to why we need this. First of all, we have the UN Sustainable Development Goals and the Paris climate agreement, which both require effective action on illegal logging and deforestation. Besides, illegal logging is a major problem in illicit capital flows from developing countries. Indeed, FLEGT has had many successes, but the global context has changed a lot since its introduction in 2003. So now we really need new measures and we need to look at innovative ways of shedding light on the supply chains. It is a very important task for us to make sure that consumers in the end—user countries, like those in the European Union, have full access to information on the origin of the timber. I believe that FLEGT could actually inspire many other sectors and products. The approach is really innovative, with the voluntary partnership agreements. One of the things that I have noticed is that the evaluation has come to the conclusion that there are limitations in terms of lack of data on illegal logging and trade and on governance achievements. Here I believe some new instruments could be introduced. We could see how customs information could be used to shed light on which companies are importing what to the EU Member States. I also firmly believe that we could look in the countries of origin at how we can support the countries to put in place proper systems of forest inventory. I am proud to say that Finland, my country, has been very active in helping countries like Vietnam and Tanzania in this field.

name: Julia REID
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, illegal logging is symptomatic of wider governance problems, such as weak and unclear laws, corruption, big business behaving badly and poor local people with few incentives to behave well – all brought about by scientific theories which have been preached with the certainty of religious fervour. This, with the assertion that the rule of law means the same everywhere, is not a pretty picture, and it applies to much in the developing world – especially in the issue of industrial scale illegal logging and deforestation, which is threatening the survival of some of the world’s most endangered animal species.  There is a stupid response to rush to criminalise in ways which further incentivise bad behaviour, based on questionable science, and to reinforce this with due diligence bureaucracy which adds to costs, thus further incentivising the very activity that we want to stop. If you raise the price of something, you encourage new market entrants, including illegal ones. What is needed is to ask the Commission whether it has done a robust behavioural economic analysis of the incentive system in the global logging market. This is, of course, not the kind of question asked by or of the European institutions. Instead, we have the usual cliché buzzwords: ‘political momentum’, ‘coherence’, ‘synergies’, ‘climate’, ‘mitigation’. Thank goodness my country is leaving.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, the Special Report 13/2015 of the European Court of Auditors describes the failure of the European programme to support timber-producing countries in the fight against illegal logging. This scourge threatens the world's forest heritage, but also the indigenous peoples who depend on the forest for their livelihoods.  The reasons for these illegal loggings are diverse. First, in Indonesia, a large number of trees are cut down to make way for plantations that will produce paper or palm oil, destroying biodiversity. In South America, illegal logging is used to export this wood to organizations sometimes linked to corrupt authorities who, of course, want to enrich themselves by meeting the demand for wood on international markets. The loggers are pursued when they are victims of a system that exploits them and, of course, the decision-makers are never arrested.  In addition to corruption, the fight against illegal logging is not always the priority of the government of the country in question. The expansion of palm oil or soybean fields to support intensive agriculture is part of the problem.  Finally, the last problem is the traceability of products on the market. For example, 80-90% of the timber exported from Peru to China and other Asian markets is illegal, which corresponds to a loss of about 86 million euros. Finally, I think that developing and hardening the traceability imperative would be a good solution. Given the complexity of the problem, knowing where the wood comes from and knowing the logging company obviously appears to be a credible and entirely feasible solution.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). Mr President, the importance of the existence of forests on a global scale is great, not only because they contribute to the reduction of greenhouse gases, especially carbon dioxide, thereby limiting climate change, but also because they are an important source of wealth for the countries that have them. Therefore, the protection of forests from illegal logging and deforestation must be treated by the European Union as a matter of first priority.  The European Union must draw up a policy on this subject and cooperate not only with the Member States of the Union, but also with those States which produce large quantities of wood, in order to limit illegal logging and trade in goods whose production entails deforestation. At the same time, it must properly finance this effort and conclude the necessary trade agreements in order to enable the programme to succeed.  Finally, the issue of limiting both illegal logging and forest disasters caused either by fires, arson or incidents must also be addressed within the European Union.

name: Elisabeth KÖSTINGER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work on this I would like to point out once again, and I think it is important to stress that today's debate is not a sign of our European forest owners, who have been cultivating our green treasure for generations with sustainable forest management. What is at stake today is to join forces so that the trade in illegal timber is finally stopped. Worldwide, a forest area the size of a football field is illegally cleared every two seconds, and reliable data on illegal logging in third countries is still very difficult to access. However, it is estimated that 1.2 billion euros of illegal timber is sold in the European Union every year. The economic damage to the timber-producing countries is therefore enormous. Every year they lose eur 10 to 15 billion in revenue, and this money, especially in view of the immense challenges, especially in the Member States – on the African continent – is really of particular importance here. Ladies and gentlemen, we have a responsibility here for future generations, because in addition to the economic damage, illegal logging is also a massive intrusion into our global ecosystem. FLEGT is the European Union's response to the global problem. The concept is innovative and absolutely right. However, the Court of Auditors' special report highlights massive transposition deficits. There is a great need for explanation here: what are the Commission's concepts here? Above all, how can we encourage the partner countries to reform? How can we support them? And is there really a forward-looking strategy here?  As rapporteur for the voluntary partnership agreements with Indonesia, Liberia and Central Africa, I would also like to ask the Commission for a progress report on the implementation of these agreements.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, in March 2015 I addressed in plenary the issue of illegal deforestation of tropical forests, the conflict with agriculture, the role of corruption and the loss of diversity. Today, I focus on the action plan drawn up by the European Commission, as its implementation lacks clarification, objectives and priorities.  It's hard to understand some of the options. For example, under this plan a voluntary partnership agreement was established with Liberia, which included support of EUR 12 million, but this country exports only EUR 5 million in timber to our territory. Côte d'Ivoire, which exports a value 30 times higher to Europe, has been left out. If it had been included it would ensure the environmental and social adequacy of this wood. In addition to being a serious environmental problem, it is an unfair competition with our producing regions that are making a certification effort, such as the Azores, portuguese islands of which I am of origin and which are in the center of the Atlantic.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Dear President, we will easily agree on the situation in Latin America and we know that the over-production of palm oil in various countries has caused great logging, that unplanned bad agriculture has also done great damage to our planet. But I want to talk about Europe, I want to talk about us, I want to talk about the problems we face in the Member States of the European Union where there is also illegal logging, forest theft, wood theft and where there is a theft of resources of people living surrounded by forests.  A concrete example is Gorski Kotar in Croatia. A missed policy that the state has been running for 25 years, which is why young people leave Gorski Kotar because they do not see their perspective and their future, and are surrounded by square kilometres of first class forests. Poor state policy that does not take care of the local community and thus does not allow the fantastic resources that Gorski Kotar has to be used for the benefit of the development of citizens of this small but beautiful part of Croatia. I think we should talk about such topics as well, Mr. Commissioner.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: – Mr President, the commitments and measures contained in the Action Plan remain relevant, but their effectiveness will be less if it is not strengthened, as the Commission acknowledges. And it will be ineffective if the European Union does not guarantee its full implementation, such as that of the Regulation on the marketing of wood. The circulation of illegally extracted timber, which violates forest protection regulations and the rights of native populations, must be stopped. We need additional measures, such as those mentioned by my colleague Lidia Senra, to protect biodiversity, forests and forest peoples. In 2015, Member States recognized the need for urgent action when they committed to the sustainable development goals and the Paris Agreement on climate change. I believe it is time to meet these commitments and close the gaps in the Action Plan.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. The problem of the illegal use of forest resources and the risks posed by such activities concerns not only environmental aspects, but also economic and social aspects. Misuse of forests causes significant damage not only to the environment. In addition to deforestation, biodiversity loss and increased greenhouse gas emissions, illegal logging contributes to conflict among indigenous and local communities, human rights violations and corruption. The proceeds of these activities are often used to finance armed conflicts, contributing to an increase in poverty levels. In Africa, nigeria, Tanzania, Zimbabwe and the Democratic Republic of congo have suffered the greatest losses in the forestry sector in recent years. The authorities of some of these countries use the so-called controlled firing of forest areas to harvest these lands for cultivation.  Tackling negative trends, including illegal logging, requires close cooperation with developing countries, where the use and trade of timber is important for the economy. Support is needed for the exchange of good practices and for appropriate forest policy reforms. Therefore, the FLEGT Action Plan aimed at increasing developing countries' capacity to control the illegal use of forests – while restricting trade in illegal timber products between these countries and the European Union – is a good attitude. However, additional resources should be allocated to address the challenges of its implementation and monitoring.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, illegal logging and trade in illegally cut timber generates an economic loss of €7 billion annually. Even more significant is the extremely unfavourable impact on biodiversity and the level of greenhouse gas emissions, and this consequently affects the lives of people who depend on forests, distorts the market and, certainly, encourages corruption. The European Union Action Plan for forestry law enforcement, governance and trade (FLEGT), although in theory well conceived, failed in practice. This is why it is necessary to revive this political initiative as soon as possible and exploit its potential. In addition, it is time to stimulate interest in the state of forests in the European Union. Excessive, illegal logging and trade in illegally cut wood is not only a problem for third countries with which we conclude FLEGT agreements, as all this also happens on a daily basis in our Member States. In Croatia, roads and roads that have been built for decades are being destroyed, and illegally felled timber is mainly taken to neighbouring countries and placed on the market without control. For this reason, I call once again for enhanced activity and coordination when it comes to the conservation of Europe's forests. Forests are much more significant than they seem to us; they are the lungs of Europe, a source of energy, a guardian of climate and biodiversity and should be respected in accordance with their utmost importance.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in times of climate change, forests become the only ally for safeguarding the life and well-being of millions of human beings. In addition, they represent the most important reservoir of biodiversity and a constituent element for indigenous communities and farmers around the world.  Europe remains the first destination for the illegal trade in timber, and that is why it is crucial in the coming years that there is a real commitment from the whole Union to ensure that the FLEGT does not remain a voluntary commitment within the framework of trade agreements. We need binding commitments to regulate the activities of governments and multinationals and, at the same time, to block the corrupting system. It is essential that the reform of the FLEGT explicitly prohibits trade in timber from conflict zones, providing for a system of sanctions until import licences are revoked and free trade agreements or preferential tariffs for multinationals and states that violate the embargo are suspended. Finally, we consider the system of voluntary monitoring of investments in the forestry sector by agricultural and financial multinationals to be inadequate. Instead, we need effective regulation and due diligence mechanisms that can limit illegal activities and provide hope for the planet's green lungs.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, first of all I think it is important to note that the report of the European Court of Auditors is quite devastating in its observations. In short, it tells us that political intent is good and innovative, but that this Action Plan— which in itself should not be bad — is not implemented by a good work plan, or if it arrives, it does so late and bad. It seems also a good summary of the perception of the ills affecting the Union: well thought out, but we are late and bad. We must act with a global vision, because deforestation is a serious environmental and human problem, but we must act well. In 2015, it is estimated that there were one hundred thousand deaths in Indonesia attributed to forest fires. Indonesia, which in 2014 surpassed Brazil in the dubious honor of being the country with the largest annual deforestation in the world. Indonesia, which received ten million euros for the fight for forest law enforcement, governance and trade in 2004; and, since then, the European Union has not scheduled any other development aid projects for the Government of this country in the forestry sector.  However, we must not be pessimistic, but – as the report itself says – see it as an opportunity to improve the approach given to it today, to have more tangible results, which we have also had.  The same fund has been successful, for example in Cameroon, where it has succeeded in engaging civil society in forest governance.  We must stress the need to recognize the environmental but also social and economic value of forests. We must remember the added value they place on rural populations, including activities such as grazing that help prevent hazards such as forest fires, as well as maintain a clean forest.  That is why I would like to highlight this Parliament's kostinger report on a new EU strategy for forests and the forestry sector in which we are calling for an action plan on deforestation and degradation in order to address the objectives set out in the Communication on the protection and improvement of forests through sustainable management , as well as support for mechanisms that promote the global development of forestry with a view to more sustainable exploitation of forests.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: – Mr President, the EU Action Plan on Forest Law Enforcement, Governance and Trade (FLEGT) and its implementation have fundamentally helped to increase awareness of the devastating impact of illegal logging. The commitments and measures contained remain highly relevant today and should be further strengthened. Governments have recently committed themselves to the Sustainable Development Goals and the Paris Agreement. If the European Union wants to remain a credible global partner and a global force in combating climate change, we have to take concrete actions, cooperate with international partners, and increase the coherence of EU policies to effectively push for ending deforestation and the connected violations of human rights.  Tackling deforestation and illegal logging can be successful only if indigenous peoples’ land rights are respected. The EU Action Plan needs strong governance reforms, coherence with other environmental policies and additional resources. We should express our firm position on some particular points of the problem, which I believe are essential to achieving the concrete picture of what the European Union plans to undertake.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, Commissioner, it is important to support timber producing countries and mobilise resources for the development of mechanisms in order to strengthen the Union's action plan for the implementation of forestry legislation. But all our action must respect and promote the climate and environmental objectives we have set. It is necessary to take immediate measures to prevent and prevent illegal logging, arbitrary deforestation, but also the deliberate destruction and burning of forests carried out with a view to the land use of forest land, which we live very strongly in Southern Europe, and to serve large private interests. It is also important to promote afforesis. Environmental protection is a key condition for upgrading the quality of life of man. We therefore have a duty to protect forests from all forms of illegal deforestation and destruction and to develop forest legislation based on the interests of society and people.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, In my one minute, I would like to support all my colleagues who have performed here, because, in my opinion, illegally harvested wood actually threatens the lungs of the world. In this sense, I would particularly like to support the starting points set out in the Action Plan. On the other hand, I really feel that we are lagging behind in its implementation and in the international field, because this action plan should, in my opinion, be directly linked to the European Union's foreign policy. We, too, should be able to support those states that do not really respect the commitments that may even have been contractually agreed with our Union, precisely on the international stage. I was in Singapore a few years ago and I was really appalled at how the smoke from Indonesia even hit this state and just comes from the forests being burnt and concerns palm oil. I think that we should not resign from these facts and we should support our policy in this very foreign area as well.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as a result of the european Union's prominent, but not dominant, position in the world market for wood products, any measure will be ineffective if not shared with the major players in the sector, such as the United States, Japan and China. I believe that the Commission must give political impetus to the European Union's action plan for enforcement, governance and trade in the forestry sector, completing the creation of a voluntary licensing system, aimed at ensuring the import of only legally cut timber. In order for such a system to function properly, FLEGT partner countries should establish reliable systems and structures for the correct identification and certification of the link of wood cut. With regard to the financial aspect, the Commission should integrate the initiatives provided for in the FLEGT programme into the main European development cooperation programmes, in order to be able to implement technical assistance and capacity-building programmes in the timber-producing partner countries.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, illegal logging and deforestation are having a serious impact on the environment, as they reduce biodiversity and contribute negatively to climate change. To tackle environmental disasters caused by illegal logging and deforestation, the European Union has since 2003 adopted an action plan on forest law enforcement, governance and trade, with the aim of encouraging sustainable forest management. This action plan has not yet produce the desired results. According to the Court of Auditors of the European Union, the EUR 300 million allocated to 35 countries under the project has had poor results.  The Commission should therefore take immediate measures to combat illegal logging and deforestation. At the same time, Mr Vella, the Union should financially support Greece in order to repair the damage suffered by producers and their plant and livestock from the recent fires in Chios, Evia and Corfu. The same must of course apply to Cyprus, which also suffered from fires this year.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, this is a most interesting discussion and a serious issue for the world generally. I would hope, particularly now that we have 195 countries signed up to COP 21, that this is an issue that should be easier to tackle globally – especially now as we go to Morocco and try to implement the agreement that was signed in Paris in December. That should certainly help. Also of interest is that in my own constituency there is an innovative company called Treemetrics who log, map and monitor what is happening in forests through satellite imagery. That might be useful, especially in tracking illegal logging, etc., and is something that might be worth looking at. I was very encouraged, though, to hear that progress has been made, for instance, in Indonesia. In the space of 14 years, there was a 70% reduction in illegal logging due to bilateral arrangements and discussions. I think, as the Commissioner pointed out, that Ghana and other countries will hopefully follow in due course.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, illegal logging and deforestation are huge problems in several EU Member States. We are also experiencing a well-known phenomenon in this area: while we have legislation to address this issue, the reality of everyday life is that corruption-insated systems have been built to continue uncontrollable logging on an industrial scale. Entire forests are being lost, public authorities are turning a blind eye in many cases, and local forest owners are powerless. Information circulates as an open secret that logging companies buy, process and sell illegally harvested timber, with no concern for environmental and other aspects. There seems to be no consequence of the legislation being passed, and citizens expect the law to apply to everyone: even companies that process millions of cubic metres of wood and provide hundreds of jobs.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: Member of the Commission – Mr President, I would like to thank all the Members for their statements, comments and suggestions, to which I have listened very carefully. I have to say that I agree with many points that have been raised. I will also communicate these to my colleagues, Neven Mimica, Miguel Arias and Cecilia, with whom I work very closely on deforestation issues. It has already been mentioned that progress is being made even with some timber producers, and in a few weeks’ time we will see the launching of FLEGT licensing in Indonesia. I think this is a major step and one we hope will be followed by Ghana next year. At the moment we are discussing VPAs with some 15 other countries. So there should be no doubting the Commission’s commitment to making FLEGT work. There were also some interesting points which were made like, for example, Mr Tomašić, who mentioned the joint surveillance between Member States, and the fact that we still have illegal timber coming into Europe, and  I have to stress again the responsibility of the Member States.  There is also the fact of the link between deforestation and the agricultural sector, especially the fact that we have to find monoculture and so on, and the socio-economic impact as well. I think many of you also spoke about inadequate implementation and I have to say yes, the Commission acknowledges that the absence of an implementation plan to guide strategic management and monitoring has rendered implementation of FLEGT, and VPAs in particular, largely demand-driven. That is why the Commission is working towards the development of a multiannual plan to guide activity planning by setting clear targets, indicators, monitoring deadlines and associated budgetary resources. Many of the honourable Members also mentioned the corruption problem. I totally agree with what they said, and that is why we took a number of precautions, especially in VPAs. The scheme developed for VPAs has several layers of safeguards and independence. Firstly, compliance with legal requirements is checked by private certification companies. Secondly, a specific role is provided for civil society to check that audited enterprises and forest operators comply with legal requirements. Thirdly, there is an overall systems audit, or periodical evaluation, that is foreseen and that will be carried out at least on an annual basis to check that the system is working properly overall. There were several mentions of dealing with SDGs and climate change, and many of the action plan’s areas of action contribute to addressing several goals of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, including SDG 8, SDG 12 and SDG 13, which is climate change, SDG 15 which is life on land and SDG 16, which is peaceful and inclusive societies. What the Commission intends to do: as indicated in the 7th Environmental Action Plan, the Commission remains committed to developing policy proposals to address the deforestation challenge, and to this end the Commission is in the process of considering the feasibility of measures to achieve this objective, also as a follow-up to the study on the impact of EU consumption on deforestation. We will continue to ensure adequate resources for the implementation of the action plan, through the development and cooperation instrument, including support for the engagement of civil society, private sector and public administrations. When we talk about resources, as Notis Marias mentioned, we have not only to monitor and talk about input but, more importantly, I think we need to monitor the output as well. As the Court’s report found, the fundamentals of the FLEGT Action Plan are right. It is making an important contribution to mitigating climate change and to improving governance by clarifying tenure rights but, I agree, still more needs to be done. The Commission is also acting to address the important recommendations of the Court to ensure that the action plan is fit for purpose in a world where the pressures on forests are increasing.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. – Forests occupy significant areas of the planet and are important ecosystems for both humans and ecologically. In order to achieve the objectives of the 2020 Strategy for forests, I believe that it is necessary to strengthen the strategy for forests and the forestry sector by: the fight against deforestation and forest degradation, the promotion of sustainable forest management as a means of protecting biodiversity, the fight against desertification and responding to climate change, while ensuring that forest ecosystems provide goods and services, contributing to sustainable development and poverty eradication. Strong commitment, coherence and political support from all parties involved in the FLEGT Action Plan are needed so that development and climate change policies place forests and the forestry sector at the heart of the move towards a green economy and highlight the benefits that forests can offer in a sustainable way , while ensuring their protection and combating illegal deforestation.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. – In implementing the Paris agreement that we will confirm these days, it is imperative that every country in the world assumes responsibility and contributes to the achievement of the set goals. In implementing its energy and climate policy, the EU must also ask others to contribute to the conservation of its forests by following its example. It is on this track that I believe that the sustainable use of forests as we know it in Europe must also be a condition for trade with third countries when it comes to imports of wood and timber. A FLEGT permission is a voluntary framework within which the desired objectives can be achieved. I consider it positive to highlight the example of Indonesia, which has raised the proportion of certified logging from 20% to 90% since 2002, thus demonstrating its commitment to the conservation and sustainable use of its forests. This is important for us because the EU imports almost a third of its tropical timber needs from Indonesia. I consider it necessary, and as the Court of Auditors also stresses in its report, to concrete actions through mechanisms to monitor and assess the performance of the implementation of the EU Action Plan on forestry enforcement, governance and trade. The existing method of voluntary certification needs to be further strengthened in order for other countries to achieve the protection of their forests at least up to the level of their sustainable use.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the one-minute speeches on matters of political importance under Rule 163 of the Rules of Procedure.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: – Mr President, it is 60 years since the Hungarian people rebelled in october 1956 in unprecedented unity against the Communist dictatorship and the Soviet Bolshevik rule that invaded its country. The Hungarian Revolution and The War of Independence of 1956 continued in the Prague Spring in 1968 and the Polish Solidarity Movement in the 1980s. In the life-changing year of 1989, the common struggle of our peoples in Central and Eastern Europe led to the fall of Soviet communism and the regime change to the reunification of a divided Europe. Freedom is one of the main fundamental values of the European Community. It is worthy to remember the Hungarian '56 and those who sacrificed their lives for freedom as one of the most outstanding events in our common history. Following their example, we must continue our fight against all repressive powers and totalitarian regimes.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, by 2020, Italy will have to ensure inclusive growth by 2020, creating as many as 2.8 million new jobs, and remove some 2.2 million people from poverty or deprivation. Unfortunately, eight Italian regions are still far from reaching the national target set for 2020 and among the regions with the greatest difficulties are all those of the Mezzogiorno, with a gap to be recovered from 8.4 % in Abruzzo to 23.9 % in Campania and 24.9 % in Calabria. Va has put in place a major action plan, a plan that includes reforms and investment in social housing, physical and digital infrastructure and educational infrastructure.  The Italian Government, especially in the last period, is doing a great deal to improve the country's conditions for development and job creation, but it is clear that the contribution of Europe is also needed to achieve the goals set out in the Europe 2020 strategy. We need a more flexible and expansive economic policy to enable our country to overcome its difficulties and reach its targets.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – The unreasonable and confused common policy of concentrating illegal immigrants in centres in populated areas has created extreme difficulties, a threat to public order and security, a threat to the security and health of citizens around these centres. All around Ovcha Kupel, Vrajdebna, Harmanli citizens protest against these centers and demand that they be closed.  I will briefly read you a declaration adopted by the general assembly of the population in harmanli yesterday, which requires that the registration and reception center in harmanli be removed from the city. An immediate termination of the public procurement for the expansion of this center and for the construction of new centers in the settlements is required. A police check is required for the illegal residence of migrants at external addresses. European Union action is required to conclude a readmission with Afghanistan. An immediate change in the laws is required so that illegal migrants are turned away. Dear Mr President, honourable Members, we need a new migration and asylum policy. We will not allow our homeland to be turned into a camp for illegal migrants.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Mr President, there was always a contradiction at the heart of the argument that said ‘we will control our borders while keeping access to the single market’. Those lies were laid bare by Theresa May last weekend. There were no weasel words from Mrs May. She laid it on the line when she said: ‘we will decide for ourselves how we control immigration and we will be free to pass our own laws’. The most important word there is ‘ourselves’. There is no attempt at negotiation; no soft Brexit. She is setting the parameters.  This has the potential to be catastrophic for Ireland in so many ways, but particularly for some of our indigenous industries, particularly the agri-food sector. By comparison, 7% of German exports go to the UK, 17% of Irish exports go to the UK. The British will be hard-nosed in their negotiations. We in Ireland must move swiftly and sure-footedly to protect our interests. We are entering a critical time. As we say in Ireland: ‘we are playing senior hurling now’.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, the tripartite meeting in New York between the leaders of the two communities in Cyprus has recently ended. Since we do not know whether we will be faced with a great success of the European Union, whether a solution is achieved, or whether this will collapse, with all the risks that this entails, taking into account what is going on in the surrounding area, I would like to give some thoughts on the need to resolve the Cyprus problem and its parameters. We therefore call for the withdrawal of turkish occupying troops in the solution and abolition of the anachronistic system of 1960 guarantees, as well as any unilateral interventionist rights. My party rejects any NATO solution to the security issue.  Secondly, we call for the continuation of the Republic of Cyprus and its evolution into a Bi-Community Bi-League Federation. We call for a seamless application of basic freedoms and human rights for all Cypriot citizens. We do not accept permanent deviations from the acquis communautaire. We demand an end to settlement and respect for the population ratio of 4 to 1. We call for substantial territorial adjustments, such as the accession, inter alia, of Famagusta and Morfos under Greek Cypriot administration. We consider it necessary to minimise the timetables for both the return of territory and the withdrawal of occupying troops and we call, finally, for a strong Security Council resolution and other related commitments by all parties involved to ensure the implementation and faithful observance of the overall settlement.  I would like to conclude, if I may, with a reference to Şener Elcil, who was awarded the European Citizen's Prize the other day and, despite the protection this award should give him, faces threats. I think Parliament should keep its eyes open on this issue.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: – Mr President, Theresa May has outlined her great repeal bill, but nothing will happen for six months until Article 50 is triggered in March next year. Two years of negotiations will then follow to arrive at the elusive deal supposedly required before the UK can leave the EU, and we won’t actually leave until April 2019. By then, we will have had another two-and-a-half years of uncontrolled EU immigration and not a single EU law will have been repealed. There is a much simpler solution. Forget Article 50. Repeal the European Communities Act and return supremacy to our parliament. Introduce emergency legislation on immigration and border controls. Offer the EU a choice: continued mutual tariff-free access to the single market, or trade under WTO terms. The choice is theirs. Existing EU directives would continue to apply until amended or repealed by parliament. That is the way to make Brexit mean Brexit now.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Mr President, the European Union was built against the will of the people. She's paying a lot of money today. After the British people, who voted for Brexit, it is the hungarian people's turn to teach them a lesson in direct democracy. 98% of Hungarians who took part in the referendum on 2Nd October voted against the reception of 1,300 migrants that the EU wanted to impose on Hungary. Even though only 40% of registered voters moved, it is a clear score. The consequence is clear: the European plan to relocate 160,000 migrants will not be implemented. This is a resounding victory for the people on the crazy immigration policy programmed by Brussels.  60 years after its revolt against the Soviet Union, Hungary rebelled against the European Union. The European soul is still alive, resistance to the destruction of national identities is organized. Tomorrow, France will give the Union the coup de grace by voting in a referendum for Frexit.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I am very sorry, but I will be talking about a very similar subject – not so much about Hungary as it is about the European Parliament, because I am amazed that I hear words about democracy every now and then in this Parliament, but when something is being done democratically in Hungary, because indeed a majority – ninety-eight percent of voters are true – and therefore this percentage is much higher than the percentage who want to vote for Mrs Clinton in America. , then the Union wants to discuss the situation in Hungary.  Well, I wanted to point out that if someone is a Democrat – me and I am not a Democrat – but if you are a democrat, then you have to acknowledge that most Hungarians want something. And I am just glad that the European Union does not yet have an army, because if the European Union had an army, it would certainly have already provided assistance to the Hungarian people, just as the Soviet army, as Mr Tőkés remembers, carried this aid in 1956.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. We Hungarians always decide in a referendum on the most important issues affecting our future, as was the case yesterday. It is clear that the Hungarians have decided who they want to live with and who they do not want to live with. This referendum clarified the position of the Hungarians. The mandatory resettlement quota package involves a significant economic, cultural and security risk and we cannot assume it. Thank you to everyone who went to vote. Those who stayed at home left that decision to the others. I think this decision is about our future, it's about our children. I respectfully ask the democratic European Union, as it did in the event of Brexit, to respect the decision of the Hungarian people to do so. 3 million 300 000 people have decided to say no to this mandatory quota package. Nine out of 10 people chose to say no. A lot of people want us to bully these 3 million 300,000 people, but that's a lot more than the number of people who voted yes to join the EU. In fact, it is much more than the number of votes we received in 2014, when we were confirmed in government – exactly 1 million more. Turnout is 10% higher than in the EU vote. Thank you, Mr. President. Please respect our decision.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Honourable colleagues, honourable Representatives of the Commission, i would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent work. Me miyvars Saqartvelo — translated from Georgian means "I love Georgia". I think and I am sure that the majority of Members who are Members of the European Parliament could say the same. Then I have a counterquestion: why did we, the European Union, deceive Georgia? Why do we, the European Parliament, do not know what is happening in the Council, and the Council of the European Union is at the moment a brake that is actually preventing the introduction of visa-free travel between Georgia and the European Union at the moment. I am ashamed, colleagues, because in the current situation of the crisis in the European Union, we do not have very many friends, but Georgia is one of allies and friends. I call on the European Parliament to be actively involved in this process and to introduce visa-free travel with Georgia.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by On my return for the first time, I wanted to thank you for the concern that the European Parliament has been caring about Poland over the last year by introducing debates on the rule of law and women's rights. It is only a pity that similar assistance was not offered under previous governments, when many areas of life were destroyed, provoking the multimillion-dollar emigration of my compatriots – mostly young, educated and enterprising. It's easy to destroy, it's harder to rebuild what the current government is trying to do. The extent of the destruction and the depth of destruction in one only – moral – aspect could be seen in Poland today, when the Black Monday was organized. There have been marches and strikes by black-clad supporters of the civilization of death, who, instead of mourning the millions killed in the majesty of the rights of unborn children, continue to fight in total shame for the barbaric right to kill babies conceived in the womb of mothers.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, exactly a year ago, at the be behalf of European citizens, we adopted the resolution on the right to water. At that time, we demanded, in a final way, that the Commission not in any way promote the privatisation of water undertakings under economic adjustment programmes or any other Union procedure and permanently exempt water services from the rules of the internal market and from any trade agreement, as well as to provide them at affordable prices. Yesterday, the Quartet, in cooperation with the willing and obedient Greek government, has put Greece's water and sanitation in the Privatisation Super fund for 99 years. Fortunately, the Greek Minister of Finance, Euclid Tsakalotos, said that, as long as he is minister, they will not be sold. It seems that all we have left to defend both the dignity and the reason for the existence of the European Parliament and the gravity of our resolutions is to force either the Quartet to anoint Mr Tsakalotos as Permanent Minister of Finance for the next 99 years or the Commission to comply with our resolutions. Unfortunately, Mr President, both seem just as unrealistic.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI). Mr President, erdoğan's statements challenging the Treaty of Lausanne are particularly dangerous, as are those of the Turkish Republican Party which raise non-existent sovereignty issues for 16 Greek islands and raise the issue of grey zones and borders, thus enduring the timeless provocation expressed by the constant violations of Greek maritime and airspace, with the constant provocations against Cyprus. , by challenging the Exclusive Economic Zone. It reveals what a Greece-Turkey alliance means within NATO and what so-called "European borders" mean, when the European Union and NATO encourage Turkish aggression in the name of the European Union-Turkey agreement and the dichotomy solution promoted on the Cyprus issue.  The fact that a Commissioner of the European Union is also raising the non-existent issue of the Chamides shows how dangerous the European Union is and those who support it, such as the SYRIZA-ANEL government, since the European Union is contesting borders and restoring former Nazi collaborators. The peoples in their struggle must be vigilant against all forces that either are complacent or cultivating nationalist hatred.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Mr President, yesterday the British Prime Minister announced her intention formally to trigger Article 50 by the end of March 2017. Politically, socially and economically, Brexit has enormous consequences for the island of Ireland. It is said that Ireland is the country that will be most affected by Brexit. We export 50% of our beef, 60% of cheese and 85% of our agricultural products to the UK. But the most important issue I want to comment on tonight is the peace process. A lot of time, effort and energy has been invested, with the help of the European Union, in ensuring that there is peace on the island of Ireland. Communities live together side by side, there are no divisions, there is free movement of people across the border. We have agencies such as Tourism Ireland and InterTrade Ireland working on an all-Ireland basis, promoting the island of Ireland and activities on the island of Ireland. We do not want to see that border reinstated. We want to ensure that the implications of such a border are recognised: that there could be a negative influence on the peace process, which has been supported by the European Union. I would ask this House, and everybody here, to bear in mind the peace process and the border in Ireland. We do not want to see that border reinstated, and it behoves everybody to pay due attention to that issue.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: – Mr President, only 40% of the electorate took part in or voted validly in yesterday's referendum in Hungary. The other nearly 5 million citizens boycotted this shameful charade, or a small number voted invalidly. This means that the referendum forced by Orban was invalid and fruitless. The referendum showed that Orban's far-right hate politics do not have a majority in Hungary today. Orban has been defeated, the democratic Hungary has won, and no lying government propaganda can change that fact. The majority of Hungarians chose the spirit and values of the European Union. The Hungarian Democrats deserve the support of the European Union, because this referendum was also about Europe, about common European values, about the future of Europe. With this result, the European Union can take the liberty of not seding to blackmailers and consistently confronting far-right populism much braver than before.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I'll change the subject a little bit.  A few days ago, celebrations were held to commemorate the 75th anniversary of the Babi Jara massacre near Kiev, where between one hundred and one hundred and fifty thousand people, including at least thirty-four thousand Jews, were murdered. In addition to the Jews, the main victims of the crime, poles, Roma, guerrillas, Soviet soldiers and representatives of the Ukrainian elite, as well as members of ukrainian nationalist organizations, were also killed here. The later story of Babi Jaru – the story of attempts to fortify the past – is instructive. Today, too, we are not free from such tendencies. Bearing in mind the intricacies of history, out of respect for the victims, we should make it clear who, what country, what nation in this country organized, was the perpetrator of this crime. We should remember what kind of ideology it is, what aspirations motivated this crime.  We should not accept eugenics in any form. Today's neo-Nazi mannerisms of casting all political competitors on the right as fascists are also a sign of disrespect for the victims and a desire to disrupt the past.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: – A Uachtaráin, ba mhaith liom tacú leis an méid atá ráite ag na Feisirí ó Éirinn maidir le Brexit, ach táim anseo chun labhairt faoin gclár LEADER tráthnóna mar go bhfuil sé práinneach.  Is léir go bhfuil fadhbanna ollmhóra ceangailte leis an bpróiseas nua; is clár iontach é LEADER agus tugann sé spreagadh agus tacaíocht d’fhorbairt eacnamaíochta inár mbailte beaga agus pobail tuaithe. Tá go leor fianaise ann trí na blianta gur oibrigh sé go maith mar chlár agus gur cruthaíodh neart postanna dá bharr. Ní thuigim mar sin cén fáth go bhfuil an méid sin ciorruithe déanta insan gclár féin. Ní thuigim cén fáth gur aistríodh na rialacha agus go bhfuil sé anois faoi smacht na bpolaiteoirí seachas an pobal. Níl sé trédhearcach agus níl sé féarálta agus níl aon soiléiriú ann maidir leis an bpróiseas.  Tá an t-am anois ann don gCoimisiún ceisteanna a ardú faoin slí ina bhfuil an clár seo ag feidhmiú. Is iad ár bpobal atá ag fulaingt gan an maoiniú, agus is measa atá an scéal seo ag éirí. Ba mhaith liom go dtabharfaí aird ar an gceist thábhachtach seo.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Mr President, cohesion policy is a mechanism designed at European Union level to remove social disparities between Member States, so that every European citizen feels at home, whether in eastern or western Europe. Today in Europe, the economic crisis, the inefficient management of the migrant crisis have contributed to the rise of populism with serious effects on the future of cohesion policy. Many voices, especially in Western states, come to challenge the effectiveness of this policy, considering that there are no clear ways of expressing the benefits that citizens of the non-donor states would benefit from these investments. I would point out, however, that the states that are now net donors have benefited over time from substantial financial resources from the European Union. I also point out that this money is returning to these countries to a good extent, because almost all the investments made in the eastern countries are made by firms with techniques or materials coming from western Europe.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, since October 2015 Nnamdi Kanu, a British-Nigerian citizen and leader of the indigenous people of Biafra, has been unlawfully imprisoned by Nigeria’s Department of State Services, despite the fact that all criminal charges against him were dropped and a court order has been issued for him to be released on bail. Chapter 4, Section 39, of the Nigerian Constitution says that ‘every person shall be entitled to freedom of expression, including freedom to hold opinions and to receive and impart ideas and information without interference’. I therefore call upon the President of Nigeria, Muhammadu Buhari, to uphold his country’s constitution and to ensure Nnamdi Kanu’s immediate and safe release, as well as that of his co-defendants, Benjamin Madubugwu and David Nwauwisiare. The Nigerian Government must guarantee the freedom of expression of all Nigerian citizens, including their right to protest without intimidation, and must end the violence towards those who identify as Biafran. I call, too, on my colleagues here in the European Parliament to do much more to promote human rights in Nigeria.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: – Mr President, while many are speaking tonight on Brexit, I would like to raise another issue relating to Britain. Between 2002 and 2010 it is known that the British Metropolitan Police sent undercover police to infiltrate democratic campaign groups in Ireland, the six counties, Scotland and Germany. Some of these undercover police incited violent actions at protests. Others testified under their aliases, leading to over 50 convictions being overturned in England and Wales. More disturbing is the fact that some sexually exploited female activists and even fathered children. Despite Scotland, the North of Ireland and Germany rightly demanding answers from the British Metropolitan Police, Irish Justice Minister Frances Fitzgerald is refusing to demand how many undercover police operated in Ireland, which organisations were targeted and who authorised their presence in Ireland. Brexit will not excuse Theresa May from explaining what British undercover police were doing in Ireland. Their victims demand answers and Minister Fitzgerald should join her counterparts in demanding those answers.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, I would like to draw the attention of members of the European Parliament to the fact that in Romania the State continues to persecute the use of symbols by communities. The last time the U.S. ambassador to Bucharest experienced this was when a photo appeared in the media of him holding a Szekler flag in the company of local government leaders. In the Romanian media, this gesture was enough to cause a scandal, even the Ministry of Foreign Affairs protested against the gesture in a statement, stressing the importance of knowing existing sensitivities. Of course, not all community symbols cause such an uproar in Romania, many regions have their own flags, which they can use freely. Only the flag of Szeklerland, which is inhabited mostly by Hungarians, is protested by the Romanian authorities. And that is discrimination, even if we take into account all the sensitivities that exist. Moreover, in Romania, the court has ruled that the term Szeklerland cannot be used as a tourist destination, i.e. it is not possible to name an area by the name in which its inhabitants have called it for hundreds of years. Please decide whether this phenomenon violates European sensitivities.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: – Mr President, a few days ago Draghi, the President of the European Central Bank, recommended that Member States increase wages as one more measure for recovery. He said it for economic reasons and he was right. 80% of exports in Europe occur between Member States; wages are therefore a key measure to strengthen domestic demand and boost economic growth. But there are also more than obvious social reasons, because only living wages produce decent work, and only decent jobs and wages will produce the possibility of maintaining the welfare state. How can we make Draghi's words more of a fact than a recommendation? From the European Union we have two mechanisms: the first, the European Semester. We need to introduce this recommendation within the framework of national reform programmes. We need to encourage member states to do so. Secondly, the Socialist Group is committed to a European minimum wage framework; not for a European minimum wage, which is impossible today given the divergences, but because of a framework in which a fork is established and in which we encourage, we force member states to set a minimum to avoid this phenomenon that we are so ashamed of in Europe today, called labour poverty, that is, workers who, even sorry for the week to work , are not able to make it to the end of the month. Let's end labour poverty with the only real mechanism we have: decent jobs.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – In Uachtaráin, bhí sé de phribhléid agamsa a bheith mar ionadaí ar son na Parlaiminte i bPáras i mí na Nollag, nuair a d éirigh linn COP 21 – an comhréiteach domhanda stairiúil sin – a bhaint amach. Dar ndóigh thug an Coimisiún, go háirithe an Coimisinéir Arias Cañete, an-cheannasaíocht insna cainteanna sin.  Anois, caithfimid é a chur and bhfeidhm. Arís, tá moladh ag dul go dtí Uachtaránacht na Slóvaice mar gur éirigh leo tacaíocht a fháil ó na hAirí chun glacaint leis an gcomhréiteach sin. Anois tá an sprioc of 55% in bhí riachtanach bainte amach againn agus is féidir linn dul chun cinn maith agus éifeachtach a dhéanamh and Marrakech an mhí seo chugainn. Agus beidh mé féin ann arís, buíochas le Dia.  Ach ina dhiaidh sin, beidh orainn sa Pharlaimint agus san Eoraip ár spriocanna féin a bhaint amach agus caithfimid é sin a dhéanamh gan cur isteach ar iomaíochas an Aontais, jabanna, fás, geilleagar agus sea sin de. Ach is féidir linn é a dhéanamh má chuirimid agus oibrímid le chéile. Tá súil agam go n-éireoidh linn é sin a dhéanamh.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban's anti-European sham vote was annuled yesterday. With this, the prime minister's policies failed, Orban suffered a huge defeat. This is good news for Europe, and it is a huge victory for Hungary and for the Hungarian people. On the one hand, it is good news for Europe, because after that the Hungarian Prime Minister cannot be seen in the position that he represents the views of european little people against the political elite in Brussels, since he seems to have already become a minority in his own country, in his own country. On the other hand, this is a huge victory for the Hungarian people, because hatred has been defeated, the hate campaign on which the Hungarian Government has spent more of hungarian taxpayers' money than was spent in Britain in the referendum before britain's exit. Anywhere in Europe, the consequence would be the resignation of the Prime Minister. Orban will not resign, of course, because he will not allow his vanity, desire for power and business interests. But one thing's for sure. His downfall is getting closer! We are getting closer and closer to getting Viktor Orban to where he and extremist adventurers like him belong: the dump of history.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: – Mr President, yesterday the British Prime Minister announced that the negotiations for the UK to leave the EU would start at the end of March 2017. The lack of any commitment to the importance of the EU single market was shocking. The British Government is about to start negotiations and it cannot commit to making the EU single market a key factor in any negotiations. The single market is pivotal to the UK’s current market access for goods and services. Throw that away and you put British jobs and the UK economy at risk. Only today, we saw the fall in the value of the pound. Hundreds of thousands of British jobs rely on our accessing the EU single market. Why is it important? It is important because the single market allows us to create one set of rules that cover 20 different countries, covering 500 million citizens, allowing certainty for business and security and quality for consumers. It is no coincidence that here in this Parliament, since the single market – or  internal market – committee  was created in 2004, it has had only had UK chairs in Phillip Whitehead, Arlene McCarthy, Malcolm Harbour and currently Vicky Ford. The EU single market matters to the UK and the UK should recognise this. The UK Government should recognise this before it irrevocably damages the British economy and destroys British jobs.

name: Emilian PAVEL
text: – Mr President, the European Union is and remains indispensable to all of us. This construction has before it a future to be gained for its citizens, and I believe it will. Unfortunately, however, politicians such as Nigel Farage, Viktor Orban, Marine Le Pen or others and others also need the European Union to throw any national issues at the hands of others. What they are not saying is that the European Union exists by the will of the Member States. That the European Parliament is directly elected by citizens and that, yes, the European Commission is not a temple of technocrats, but an eminently political institution, formed by decisions taken together by the same Member States. If the European Union has a face, it is not a hidden one, as some suggest. The face of the European Union are all Member States, soon reduced, with the support of populism and demagoguery, to a number of twenty-seven. But it is all responsible for what it does and how the European Union works. This truth must be communicated to people as often as possible.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: – Mr President, the threat of suspension of European funds for Spain and Portugal is an important issue. Commitments certainly have to be fulfilled, but some other more powerful country has not fulfilled them before and nothing has happened.  It seems to me that at such a delicate time in the European Union when citizens have little affection for the Union and, above all, for the central powers of the Union, it would be really very serious if this suspension of funds occurred.  In addition, it must be acknowledged and accepted that Spain and Portugal have gone through a cruel period of crisis and austerity, and they cannot afford, as no one has paid so far, the broken dishes of this situation.
